The night before the river ran backward, I sorted bottles by the glow of my kitchen lamp and the murmur of the Oswego beyond my window. Clear to clear, brown to brown, green into the green crate I’d painted with a hand-lettered REUSE, the you curling like a fishhook. In Fulton, glass still has a decent chance of being reborn into something that won’t break under winter’s shoulder. Plastics—I hate plastics—went into their purgatory bin, labels peeled and caps saved for the boy down on Thirteenth who collects them for his art. Metal, paper, cardboard cut down to neat rectangles stacked under the sink like stale wedding cake. I order things. It’s what I do. Bring the frayed back to the hem. Persuade the cycles to keep turning.

My name is June Weaver. My mother says it was a lazy prophecy, naming a witch Weaver, but she was the sort who would drop a fortune on cunning and pick up foresight at a discount, so I forgive her. I make my living doing small repairs and larger ones, with needle and soldering iron, with nettle tea and murmured words, with alleyway whispers and the soft rasp of a file on a jagged edge. There’s a sign over my storefront on Oneida Street that reads Stitch & Solder, and most nights it twitches in the lake wind like a bird trying to settle in a questionable tree. If you come in with a broken heirloom locket, I can make it speak. If you bring me a toaster with a ghost in it, I’ll coax the specter out and into a crystal from the riverbed, where its haunting can be admired without burning your bread. I keep needles threaded in blood-red and dull gold, and a jar of greying parsley by the window for luck. I have a particular set of skills: to find what’s been misplaced, to bind what’s fallen apart, to coax electricity to behave like a good dog, to hear the creek under the tar of a road and call it by its old name until it answers.

Outside, on the long spinal street of Fulton, the bins were lined up like a makeshift parade—blue, green, open-topped with their indifferent newspapers and bottle necks. The city would swing by in the morning. The bins are not the real work; the real work is in the habit, the choice, the tiny decision repeated until it becomes a story you live inside. I rinsed my bottles and set them down easy. A habit is a spell with a longer fuse.

I slept badly that night, full of the hum of machines left too long in my shop and the churn of river ice. Sometime around two or three, there was a sound. A crackle—paper. A movement—plastic bags talking to themselves. I have no cat. I got up. My building does this thing in winter where it keeps one foot in summer. Heat rises and doesn’t settle, like bad gossip. In the kitchen my breath didn’t bloom. The window over the sink was dark with river and the streetlamp across the way smeared with a fog that had been kind enough not to be a storm.

Under the light in my kitchen, a ribbon of smoke threaded like ink. Not fire-smoke, exactly. More like the artificial sweet of heated plastic, like the inside of a toy caught in a radiator. Scan the brain: stove off, kettle cool, iron unplugged. The bins. I went barefoot, toes cracking against the cold linoleum, and down the hallway, my nightgown a puddle of dark. I took the key from the hook where I keep the key and opened the back door and stepped into the star’s breath.

The bins were tipped, the contents of my careful evening tossed like entrails. A mountain of newspaper slurry collapsed into the slick on the alley. The plastic bin had been folded cruelly, and there was a scorch mark on the rim that would not come out in the morning. The lids lay like petrified hats. Someone had scrawled with black marker on my green crate: who are you saving. No question mark. There were three cigarette butts ground into the wet cardboard as if they were answering.

I am not quick to anger. That’s not virtue. That’s practice. There are protections in my house that are not dramatic. Salt at the thresholds, iron under the rugs, a mirror turned face-down under the bed to catch nightmares like flies. I squatted in the silk pajamas my aunt Sable had sent me from New Orleans and touched the scorch mark with my fingertips. My skin prickled. The shape was not random; it was a sigil, clumsy, the kind you get when someone copies a drawing without believing in it. A triangle with a broken line through the base. I know the opacity of a triangle. This one leaked. My lips remembered the taste of black smoke, and I swallowed admiration with the cold in my throat.

“Keep your rituals to your church, June?” The voice came from the alley’s mouth, and it was a familiar ache. Eloise Tan, city councilwoman and veteran of fights you don’t know are fights until you have lost them. She had on a parka I recognized, the one with the mended cuff I’d done for her last winter that had survived a campaign and a freeze. Her hair was veiled in a hood trimmed in what looked like the fur of a white fox that had never seen blood.

“It’s my kitchen,” I said, soft to not wake the neighbors. “Anyway my church is the river.”

“Very pagan,” she said. She stepped into the alley like a detective in a TV show I used to watch with my mother, one of those where the moral is always: the city is a beast, but if you ride it right it can be a horse. She crouched next to me, sniffed like she didn’t trust me to be honest about the chemical recipe in the air. “It’s not just you. Grahams down the block, Conklin’s pizza—Etta said she found her compost slashed.”

Etta runs the co-op with a ferocity that makes you happy she uses it to feed people. Etta could fling a tomato like a grenade and you’d consent to be blown up.

“Kids?” I offered, though it didn’t feel like kids. I’ve been a kid; I know the shape of kid acts. There is a pattern then, even in chaos, and the pattern tends toward the myth of yourself you’re trying to coax from the world.

“Kids don’t leave runes,” Eloise said, pointing with a gloved finger at the triangle. “That’s cult nonsense.”

Witch, cult, church. We keep repackaging the same boxes.

“I’ll take care of it,” I said, and I meant the mark, the mess, the thing that had made both.

Eloise sighed. “I keep fighting to keep the glass program, June. If people see this, they’ll say, cut it. They’ll say, you’re feeding a thing that doesn’t want to be fed. The city is tired. The budget is the vampire we sleep with.”

“Let me be the one who worries about monsters,” I said.

“Deal,” she said, and gave me a look like a blessing. “And June?”

“Mm.”

“Maybe lock your bins.”

“Next I’ll put a gate on the river,” I said. Eloise huffed a laugh that sifted into the fog and went about her business of saving what could be saved with policy and indomitable hair.

I cleaned the alley in a nightgown and the stubbornness of a woman who doesn’t like being messed with. As I sorted, the smoke smell faded, as if embarrassed. I took the marker and wrote under the who are you saving: you. Myself. The gulls. All of us. A little petty, perhaps, but sometimes a witch writing an answer is a hex. Sometimes the hex is a way to feel less small.

Morning in Fulton is a blue that doesn’t belong to any sky more than to water. The river collects color like stories and then tells them back. The city woke. Buses snarled. A man in a tan coat that had been tan twenty years ago yelled into a phone about unions. A baby in a stroller looked at me like I was both safer and more dangerous than her mother would allow. I opened my shop as the clock over the library chimed nine, the sound too church for my taste but nice in winter when your bones look for a reason to stand. Stitch & Solder smells like wool and something like cinnamon but isn’t. I flipped the sign to open and the bell chimed like a coin dropping into a well.

Aunt Sable called as I was untangling the bracelets from the dollhouse chandelier that had been brought in by a woman who wanted to use it as a lamp for her cat’s birthday party. “June-bug,” she sang. “The river told me to call you.”

“The river has my number,” I said. “Routine complaint or emergency?”

“Don’t tease your old aunt. This is serious. There’s a shadow around your name.”

“A signature? Or a literal atmospheric anomaly?”

“Don’t get clever. It’s the kind of shadow that burns in photographs. I can see the singe.”

“Ah,” I said, and I told her about the bins. Why does telling a person who loves you always make things worse? Because then it becomes haunted twice. Once by the thing. Once by their fear.

Sable hissed—a sound like steam, like the river when it breaks free from a culvert. “Child. You staying in? You grounding?”

“My feet are on the floor, Auntie.”

“Don’t let your clever mouth run ahead of you. There’s a witch in the county who’s been burning. I’ve felt it in the mails. They don’t recycle. They aren’t reusing anything. Using. Used. Do you understand me?” She got sharp when the world got messy. She had spent her youth cleaning up messes made by men with more money than magic. Now she sits on her porch and reads the weather for people who never say please.

“They don’t recycle,” I repeated, and felt something like laughter and nausea. “How do you not recycle?”

“You throw everything away,” she said darkly. “Even if it’s yourself.”

The rest of the morning was work. A silver whistle with a cracked reed. A quilt mended from five generations of shirts. A radio with a voice that belonged to a woman whose husband had died on a Tuesday and never found the body; the woman’s voice had gotten stuck in the weather band, announcing rain when it was sunny, whispering the humidity like a secret. I set the radio on the counter and hummed to it and put my palm on its back as if it had a fever. It was a two-hour negotiation, and in the end the woman left the radio lighter and I sent the hitchhiking voice into a blue marble. The marble rolled to the wall and now holds an invisible weather system. I like to think her husband knows where he is, even if he doesn’t.

At noon Etta burst in. “You heard?” she said, not waiting for my no. “The t-shirt printer on Second? Their bins were set on fire. Actual fire. They had to call the men in hats, and now the hats want to know if it’s us.”

“Us?” I said, though I knew who she meant and she knew I knew she knew.

“Witches. He used the ‘w’ word. In a way that says he’s watched a lot of YouTube.”

“I’m tired,” I said. “I’m tired of explaining to people that the witchy things they hate are the things you do in your kitchen when you sing to the bread and swear at the roast because it burned but then you cut off the black and say it’s fine.”

“Preaching to the choir,” Etta snapped. She set a brown paper bag on my counter with a thump. “Here. Lunch. Don’t you argue.”

It was chili that smelled like it had made peace with onions. I warmed it on the hot plate with a grudge and ate it leaning against the counter because if I sat down I would stay down and the day would roll me like a log.

The rumor swelled. The internet managed to tangle itself into knots of moral clarity and conspiracy like a cat in long curtains. I ignored it on purpose for an hour. Then two. The third hour the fog stepped inside my shop like an uninvited relative and sat down on my stool. The bell over my door chimed again and there was a man whose soft wool hat was damp all the way through. He had eyes that knew the river in a way I didn’t, which is saying something. I know it by smell—mineral and fish, copper pennies and the underskirt of algae. He knew it by the way a current draws a body and how long things float.

“June,” he said, and did not offer a hand as if this was not that kind of visit. “You better come.”

“Gideon,” I said. “If you’re not my ancestor I don’t know who is.” Gideon runs the fire boat. He fishes the ones the river takes when it decides. He finds cars that have thought being water would be gentler than being road. He wears his grief like a coat he washed in cold water and then ironed because that’s what you do with sorrow; you make it presentable.

“It’s a gull,” he said. “But it’s also a message.”

I locked the shop with a chalk line like a smile over the door. Gideon and I walked the slope toward the river that made the town and in exchange asked that we handle vigilance like devotion. The river in winter is a lozenge. Bitter, medicinal. It sits. It waits. On the tattered ice near the old Nestlé plant—dead and done with sweetness decades ago—lay a gull. The gull was dead in a way that suggested it had been dead for some time, and also in a way that suggested it had been set where it was. Someone had wanted it found. Its belly was split. It was full of plastic. You hear about this. You don’t see it. I didn’t want to. Bottle caps like candy, a lighter, a comb, a tiny child’s barrette shaped like a bow that I recognized because I had sold three of them to a woman who had said they were for her niece’s dolls. Its eyes were soft and its beak was rung with a black ring of ash.

On the ice beside the bird was the same sigil as on my bin.

“Could be kids,” Gideon said, in the tone of a man who knows it could be worse.

“It’s worse,” I said.

“That’s what I thought.” He tucked his hands into his coat and watched the sky with a sensitivity animals know. “There’s talk about a witch. The city is full of talk. She doesn’t recycle.”

“She doesn’t recycle,” I repeated, but the words came out with a different weight the second time. A person who takes what works from the world and doesn’t return the favor. A person who floods the cycle with noise.

“You going to find her?” Gideon asked softly.

“I have a particular set of skills,” I said, and the sentence sounded like a joke only to people who had not seen me unsnap a curse from a doorknob or coax a laugh out of a grieving coffee cup that had belonged to someone’s father too long.

“Be careful,” he said, but his voice said: be careful of yourself.

The rumor had a shape now. A triangle with a broken base. A burner. The Black Bag Witch. The one who says: throw it in the trash, who says: it doesn’t matter, who says: sort your hopes, if you like, but please let me have this flame.

I started at the transfer station. I picked up cans with a stick and tipped over boxes that smelled like a garden that had lost its name. Nate who runs the place knows me by my temper. “June,” he said with a grin like a railroad crossing. “Forget your gloves again?”

“I like to feel what I’m feeling,” I said, and he snorted. He set me up with a vest the color of taxicabs and a pair of gloves that made my fingers feel like they were trying to read in mittens.

I walked the lines. Left a thread of myself behind like a spinning spider. I call it thread-sense, not because I’m pretty about it but because words matter. I can track a person by the way they handle a jar. The way they fold paper. The way they crumple. The way their energy sits in the discard. On the third day and the fifth hour and the eighth pile of mis-sorted plastic, I found a whorl of something that made my mouth taste like pennies. Hot, careless. The sigil again, drawn on a takeout lid with the grease from meat not from this county. Something of mine caught in the grease—hair? No. The echo of a flavor I had eaten once and said, never again.

I followed the thread out of the station and into the brownfield behind the old Hannibal mill where the grass grows tempted then bitter. You know an abandoned place by the way it remembers us without flattery. The fence had been cut by hands that knew how to cut fences with a cutter bought at a store where the clerk had looked away on purpose. Inside what might have been a warehouse or a school gym once a long time ago, a space spread out like a mouth remembering how to laugh. The floor was silt and bird droppings and broken bottles half-sunk like teeth. Someone had drawn the sigil on the chalky wall over and over, nervous scribbles that got cleaner as they went. And there was my jar of greying parsley, the one from my window, and I had not put it there.

Sable says the problem with old mills is they are hungry. They gorge on labor for decades and then when you stop feeding them they bite your hand. The mill’s hunger looked like a drift of plastic bags collected in a corner and humming a little in that way that only people like me hear. I could taste the burn on the back of my tongue. There were cigarette butts in a cracked sink; lipstick stains on the paper of a cheap cup. A black bag ripped. I crouched by the parsley—which had been emptied onto the floor in a shock of grey leaves like hair—and touched the jar’s lip. My fingerprints there, old. My print on a print. A mirror of me was here or had been here or had used my things.

I left the mill like a thief. The thread-sense went with me, stitched through my coat, bound to my ribs. I slept that night like I’d been set on a slow river that sometimes goes under and becomes a different river entirely.

Fulton is kind to stalls that sell hot sugar on sticks and fresh donuts the size of small boats. If you want a mark, you do it on a day when the whole town smells like something from an old calendar. The Green Days fair down by the lock is supposed to be merry. There are tables with pamphlets so earnest they wear a blush. There is a man with a beard so monumental it might be a monument to beards, and he has a machine that turns old t-shirts into yarn and the yarn into hats and the hats into compliments for babies. There are students with bright eyes who say: compost numbers! And there is one of those bikes you pedal to make a blender spin, and the children get to be blenders. Etta had a booth that could have been a barricade. Gideon had photographs of the river that were so beautiful you wanted to die and be water.

I had a table with a bowl of single earrings that I’d coaxed into pairs. A pot of herbs for exchange. A sign that read Free Mendings. A little line formed and stayed like weather. I sewed a button back on a coat. I unpicked the hem of a memory and pressed it open with spit and thumbs and a charm for flattening the past enough to step on. I smiled until my lips felt like local celebrities.

At one, the wind changed. These are the things you notice when your blood knows the angle of the light. It shifted from south to east, bringing with it the genius of a factory that no longer exists. People went closed, like clams. The smell sharpened. And then the bins by the municipal table—overflowing with the good intention of a thousand sample cups—flared. A flame like a tongue licked up, rolled, doubled itself like a jellyfish and kept going. There was a scatter and a shout. Someone threw a bucket at the fire, which is not a sentence so much as a confession. Water pleased the plastic for a second and then made it furious.

“Extinguisher!” Etta roared, and someone obeyed her who had never before obeyed a woman. The extinguisher coughed and the white smother fell and the fire made its thin cry and settled into a smear of shame.

On the white, in the outline, the sigil. This would have been a time to run for the person doing it. This would have been a time to say: witch-hunt, in a tone that meant, we already know how this goes. Instead I stood still, held in place by a tug somewhere in the meat of my shoulder. My shoulder aches when a hurricane is thinking about my town. It also aches when I have done something I don’t want to admit to myself yet.

“June.” Eloise’s voice had the tremor in it reserved for conversations about budgets and the deaths of good ideas. “We cannot afford this.”

“Agreed,” I said. The wind made a half-hearted attempt at playing with my hair and gave up. I tasted sugar. Melted plastic. The ghost of a carnival. I tugged my thread-sense and it snapped tight as if something had taken hold of the line and was playing. A pull; I staggered like a fish. An answer to a question I had asked in no language anyone taught me. It pulled north, toward the old Nestlé, toward the river’s one man-made apostasy.

I excused myself the way you excuse yourself from your own party when you remember there is a pan in the oven that was never in the oven to begin with. My feet were sure. Why not? They knew where I have gone in the night I’m not allowed to own yet.

The factory is a carcass. Everyone says that. They say it as if the V of broken windows can’t bite still. The smell of milk is gone, but in summer if you stand in the right place, sweet ghost. I walked past the No Trespassing sign with the humility of someone who obeys signs but not this one. Inside, in the place where chocolate used to be poured like prayer, someone had spelled out words with plastic cutlery. We don’t recycle, they had written, which was both a statement and a threat. A heap of black bags sat like a dragon hid its wealth and went cheap.

I should have called someone. That is the thing that reasonable women who are tired of mopping up after unreasonable things do. Call Gideon or Eloise or Nate or even the man with the mountain of beard and the yarn machine. Instead I put my hand on the nearest bag and felt heat. Not heat from flame. Heat from hands. Hands that had been mine, at least recently. Again the penny taste. Again the thread pulling. I took a breath and tugged. The world turned.

When I woke up, the light was the white-out of afternoons that have decided to be evenings against advice. My hands were gritty. Under my nails: grey. Ash. My pockets slick with something sweet. A smear of black on my jaw that smelled like a lollipop had had a bad idea. The heap of bags had been rearranged while I was asleep or while I was someone else. The cutlery words had been scrambled to an arrangement that made less sense but spoke to me anyway. Ecycle. Leryc. Cry. I wiped my mouth and tasted sugar and something burned. I had lost an hour or a day. Time is a substance too; you can deprive yourself of it, and then it discovers ways to deprive you in return.

On the floor someone had drawn the sigil once more. And beside it, the mark I put on things I have made so that I can find them by feel in the dark. I have put that mark on a hundred mends, tucked into seams like a whisper. I have never drawn it where anyone can see. My stomach dropped. My mark and the triangle sharing a wall like neighbors who have started to borrow sugar and then borrow other things and then one day they borrow the other’s name and no one can tell whose it was to begin with.

I wandered home with my coat open and my mind shut. The night was hungry and my house was both a shelter and a witness. I scrubbed the smear off my face and it came off too easily. I put the parsley jar back without speaking to it. I opened the drawer where I keep the good salts and I put a line around my bed so thick it might have stopped a river, and then I stepped over it like I was a teenager and the salt was a rule. Sleep came. Sleep went. There were dreams, but they were like rooms without switches.

The next day I ate toast at Etta’s because if I made my own I would teach the bread something I did not want it to know about me. I listened as people spoke in the same tone about the weather and the economy and the witch as if all three were connected and also none of them could be solved. Pastor Lennox came in and didn’t order anything and Etta gave him coffee anyway because she is more gracious than he deserves and because grace is cheaper flavoured when the person receiving it needs it. He looked at me like I was a problem he had not yet invented a sermon for. He touched his tie pin with a rhythm people who do not pray cannot hear.

“You going to the council meeting?” Eloise asked, sliding into the booth like she was an extra person in my life preserver. “They want to vote on cutting glass, June. They say the fire makes it look bad.”

“I’ll stand up. I’ll speak,” I said. “I’ll mend.”

“Good,” she said, and then, almost not letting herself, “Be careful.” She meant: be careful not to make it worse.

At the meeting there was shouting. There are two kinds of shouting: the kind that gets things moving, and the kind that lights a match. We had both. Men who had never sorted a bag of anything in their lives said words like personal responsibility. Women who have sorted their families for decades said words like community and tired. My mouth tasted like sheet cake and shame. Eloise held the line. Gideon spoke once only, and the room got quiet. He said: I pull the river’s dead out, do not make me pull out your hope. It was melodrama and it worked because it was true.

Then a woman stood up with a flyer. It was a flyer I had made last spring, for a repair night at my shop. I recognize my own italics. The sigil had been sketched in in pencil, like a mustache on a portrait. Underneath, the writing: save your scraps for the witch. My handwriting. My pen. The same curl on my y’s that Aunt Sable teases me about. I stood. Sat. A weird low note was stuck in my chest and it didn’t belong to a song.

“June?” Eloise said under her breath, grim as tax. “Is that—?”

“A copy,” I said. “A prank.”

“It would have to be a good one,” she said. She meant: the people who hate you are not usually this clever.

I went home walking on the spine of the night as if I were afraid of the edges. The alley was clean only because I had cleaned it. I set my bins inside my door like I was the kind of person who feeds a raccoon out of fear. In my mirror a girl with my hair looked out with eyes I didn’t recognize and then she blinked and was me again. I threw a bottle at the trash can and missed. It rolled under the table and came to rest against a little nest of dust I had not decided if I loved or not. Sometimes human detritus is the only proof of animals.

There are so many stories about witches and their mirrors. How we fear them. How we live in them. How a mirror is just a river made obedient. I went to the river at midnight and held my breath until the stars looked like holes poked in black paper. A voice said, I won’t recycle, and it was my voice, but I didn’t say it. I said back, that’s not what we do. The river said, do you know what you do? I have always admired water’s rudeness.

The next morning the bins on Oneida were righted and resigned. The city had not yet noticed the scare. There were new marks on the brick by my door. The triangle, yes. And a phrase that made the edges of my vision pixellate just a little. we are the same— Someone had stopped before the last word, or maybe they had decided to let the wall keep it. The chalk was the same chalk I use to mark hems. The handwriting was mine, and it had been done either while I was asleep or while I had been someone else. There was a piece of black plastic tucked into my mailbox like a love letter, curled to a stiffness that made me think of bones. I took it inside and put it on the counter and just looked at it for a while until the looking became a ritual and that made it safer.

I asked the river a question that afternoon with a net of copper wire and three dead batteries. The question was: what part of me is eating the rest? The river answered with a fish that had been born wrong, all eyes and no depth. It thrashed in my hands and I said sorry and I said it too late because that is how sorry works, and I let it go back to a thing that has no opinion about me.

A day later, a woman with a late sunburn came into Stitch & Solder with an electric kettle and a look that said she had been up all night considering moral math. “It’s broken,” she told me, and then, compulsive, the confession: “I burned my plastic bin. It was full and I was tired.”

“You want me to fix your kettle or your certainty,” I asked.

“They say there’s a witch,” she said. “They say she doesn’t recycle. That must seem small to you, what with all the other things. But I feel it. The wrongness.”

“Small things make systems. Systems make worlds,” I said. I opened the kettle. A triangle had been scratched inside, amateur, angry. The kettle’s heating element was clogged with a melt that must have screamed when it died. “Did you do this?”

She blushed, then hardened. “He said it would make it faster. He said we were just sending it somewhere else anyway.”

“He?”

“My boyfriend,” she said, and the past tense gathered at the edges like a storm hoping to become history. “He said he knew a witch who was fixing the city. He said people like me—well. You know what people tend to say about people like me.”

“Go on and finish,” I said gently.

“Poor. Busy. Stupid. He said she made fire that ate things we can’t see.”

I set the kettle down. The river was in my ears, a low insistence. “Do you know her name?”

“No. They just called her—” She squinted in the direction of memory. “Crackle.”

I’ve had many names. June, mostly, said by people who want me to stay. Bug, by Aunt Sable when she thinks she’s my mother. Witch, by people who think they’re hurting me when they’re not. A girl once called me Stitch, soft. No one has ever called me Crackle. The name sat weird in my mouth, on my tongue like a seed I didn’t want but swallowed anyway.

I took the kettle into my lap and did the mending with my best needle. When I was done, I kept the triangle for myself. It fit over my mark with a symmetry I didn’t want.

That night I waited for the other me like a date. I set the bins out with their lids latched like only a person who has had a raccoon in her flour knows how to latch. I brewed tea and I salted the doorway and I put the mirror under the bed upside down and I left my shoes pointed toward the river and I wore a hat. I don’t know why I wore a hat. I paced. Around two or three—same time, same slide—the smell came. Sweet and wrong. The window carry of the alley’s whispers. I stood in the doorway and I saw her.

She was my height. She was my hair but wrong by a degree, like a song played at a slightly different speed. She wore a coat I used to own, the green one with a patch on the elbow that looks like a leaf, and she had my shoulders like a promise. She tipped my bin and made a sigh like relief. She held the cigarette like a protest and then she thought better of it and put it out on the rim. She drew the triangle with the butt. It smeared. I stepped out, silent as a cat that hasn’t decided if it loves you. She turned her head. I saw my face and didn’t. The angle was different. The eyes—no. They were mine. She knew my fear well enough to cross the street in front of it.

“Who are you saving,” she said, my voice and not my voice, without the question mark, and then she ran. Or I ran. Or we both did in opposite directions, which maybe was the same direction.

I chased. Of course I chased. I am not the kind of woman who watches her own back and does not try to tap it. Down Oneida, over the rumor of black ice, through a lot behind a bar with a sign in the window that said, quietly, be kind. Past the library that holds all our ghosts in a neat grid. Into the mill’s shadow. Into the river’s mouth. I lost her at the place where the Nestlé stack throws a line across the ground even at night you can be burned by old light. She vanished like she knew how. And then I felt it—the tug on the thread I had woven into myself when I touched that grease at the transfer station. It pulled and I pulled back and for a second I felt my own hand in mine and it scared me so much I let go.

When I went back to my alley, the bins were not my bins. They were black bags. They were broken lids. They were the shape of a story I was still writing and couldn’t yet read. I drew a circle on my kitchen table with salt and put my palms flat and said the names of the people I love. Aunt Sable in her swamp of a porch. Eloise in her iron spectrum. Etta with her tomatoes and her uncompromising butter. Gideon in his boat. The baby who looked at me in her stroller. The gull, even the gull. And I said my own name and watched it flicker as if it were a candle I had set too near a vent.

“June-bug?” Aunt Sable said when I called her at a time that would have been rude if she were not a woman who sits up and argues with the moon. “Sweet. Tell me it. The thing you can’t say.”

“I think,” I said, and in the space after think all the possible lonelies gathered and held their breath, “I think I am the witch who doesn’t recycle.”

Her silence was a floor I lay down on. Then: “You don’t do that, child. That’s not your make.”

“I know what I do,” I whispered, the kind of whisper that probably woke the next apartment. “I put it in the right bins. I rinse. I sort. I banned plastic bags from my shop. I can’t stand the sound a bottle makes when it breaks wrong. But there are nights, Auntie. There are nights when the burn—”

“I know about the burn,” she said softly, like a confession she had been waiting to say. “Your mother—well. And me. Me too.” There was the sound of birds outside her window. Birds that eat time.

“We’re supposed to put things back,” I said. “Not to throw away the recyclable parts of ourselves. Not to light them.”

“You’ve always loved a rule,” she said. “But humans make rules because we don’t trust the river not to do what it will.”

“I have my mark next to her mark,” I told her. “In a place. In places. People are saying Crackle and I think that’s mine, too. How can that be mine?”

Sable made a sound like she was taking a pin out of her mouth. “June, every witch is two. Some are three. Some are a village. We are creatures of cycles and also of chasms. Maybe you made something to hold your scorch.”

“I don’t want it,” I said, bleak as iced-over mud.

She sighed, a heartbreak. “That is not the same as not having it.”

When I set the phone down, the salt circle had melted into a map of my kitchen I did not recognize. Outside, the bins waited for morning. The river turned over in its sleep. I stood in my doorway and listened to the city be everything it is: small and mean, kind and indelible, damp. I turned out my light and slept in my coat because I did not want to be caught naked by my other self when she came to do what I do not want to do and yet I will do if I can’t bear not to.

In the dream the gull spoke in a voice that could have been the radio lady’s or Gideon’s or Aunt Sable’s if you’ve swallowed grief long enough. It said: recycle, recycle, the word became meaningless as all useful words do when they are said without an object to love. The gull opened its beak and out fell a river bead, blue and cold. I picked it up and knew it. I had put it in a jar months ago because it was pretty and forgot it. In the dream and then in my waking hand, it was the same marble that held the weather. The marble swirled. Rain, then lightning. A circle closing. A line breaking. I dropped it and it didn’t roll far—it found the seam in the floorboards where things vanish and go to be a secret.

I do not have an answer, not at the close of this, not with the bins waiting, not with the city’s vote delayed, not with Eloise’s eyes asking what kind of ally I am if I am the problem, not with Etta’s hands red from washing more cups than any person should wash, not with Gideon’s boat, patient. I have a set of skills. I can find things that want to be found. I can bind. I can stitch the shape of a person back to the shape they think they are. I can solder cheap circuit boards until they confess their longing to be music. I cannot yet keep the other me from striking a match and smiling at the way it sounds. I can’t say she is not me. I can say this: if I find her, I don’t know whether I’m going to save her or stop her or both. It will involve a mirror. It will involve the river. It will involve winter and glass and the smell of sugar singing wrong.

For now I rinse the jar. I sort the lids. I take the chalk from the wall and rub the words until they are dust in my palm. I do not blow the dust away. I put it in a bottle. I label it. I write: evidence of a choice you have not yet made. I put it on the shelf next to the marble that holds a storm. I sleep with the sound of bags as they whisper to each other in the night. I put my shoes by the door as if that is something like a spell. I wait. I wait like the river waits. I guess that is the only spell any of us ever learned that works.The day after I admitted to my aunt what my mouth had been refusing, the light came up thin and metallic, like water that has been through too many pipes before it gets to your tap. I pushed my bins back out because I refuse to be the kind of person who lets fear make her trash king. The lids clicked in that way that satisfies a part of the brain that believes it can keep everything from spilling if it puts enough force on plastic. The street was salt-scabbed. Tires made that noise of surrender that tires make when they finally find grit. I watched a man in a neon vest try and fail to fold a tarp over a stack of newspaper from last month, and I thought about time: how it stacks, how we try to keep it dry, how it always manages to pucker and spot.

The boy from Thirteenth shuffled past with his backpack ballooning with impossible angles. He has the kind of walk you learn when nothing you own wants to fit where it should. I keep his name in my mouth and never say it because he doesn’t offer it and I’m old-fashioned that way. He accepted the bag of caps I’d been saving like the day had been waiting for him to arrive and rescue it. He put his hand in and sifted around until the clack changed into a note with tone. “They’re making harder plastic now,” he said, like a meteorologist who has stopped being surprised by storms. “It warps nastier. It goes all ugly.”

“Some of it was born ugly,” I said, unable to help it. “Some of it was born useful, then forgot.”

He pulled out a fused sheet of blue, green, and bone-white, bubbled like the bottom of a cheap casserole dish that saw the broil setting one time and never forgave you. A triangle traced itself across the warps, uninvited and too clear. He turned it in his hands and squinted. “He said it was art,” the boy said, meaning someone who isn’t good enough to be a teacher and isn’t brave enough to be an artist. “He gave it to me because it burned wrong. I tried to sand it, but it keeps the mark.”

“Keep it anyway,” I said, even though my stomach wanted me to ask him to put it in my hands so I could do the stupid brave thing where you take a live wire because you respect it. “You’ll know where it is if you need to break it.”

He smiled sideways and tucked it into the backpack’s mouth. “People keep wanting me to make dolphins,” he said, and rolled his eyes like he had just been asked to peel an orange with a backhoe. “I’m making a fox. It has ten tails.”

“Good,” I said. “Let it have as many tails as it needs to chase itself and not get tired.”

“It runs on fire,” he said with the satisfaction of someone who has named the fuel and isn't ashamed. He adjusted the straps and kept walking. When his back got small, the wind picked up, and a flurry of grocery bags did that thing where they pretend to be birds and then remember they have no bones.

Pastor Lennox showed up before I could decide whether to open or to hide. He came with a pamphlet that had not yet had the chance to be embarrassed by itself. He held it with the same fingers I’ve seen on piano players. The pin in his tie was a cross the size of a thumbnail, which means you have to look, and that’s the point. He looked at my sign, then at my hands, as if one of them was lying. “Ms. Weaver,” he said in a voice that had put many babies to sleep and convinced many men they were forgiven. “May I take a moment?”

“Of course.” I don’t do it because I’m polite; I do it because if you are rude to a man like that, he will write you a starring role in a parable nobody wants to hear.

He came two steps inside and stopped like a dog that knows the edge of a rug and the edge of a territory are the same thing. He opened the pamphlet, honored its crease. There were photos of bins on fire, cropped tight so you couldn’t see the hands. There were words like stewardship and words like danger, and there was a grainy capture that could have been anyone with my bones moving the world with their shoulders. “We want to help,” he said, which documented a want, not a plan.

“Do you?” I asked, because my mouth has never been obedient when a word offers itself like a bridge and turns out to be a plank.

He nodded as if nodding was an argument that required no supporting text. “Repentance is a form of sorting,” he said, as though he was giving me a bag with compartments. “You take what you’ve done and you put it where it belongs.”

“Do you sort your recycling, Pastor?” The question came out too sharp, and I wished for a second I could bend it.

His mouth tightened in the way of people who know the answer will be used as a story no matter what it is. “My wife does,” he said finally, and then, quickly, like a boy trying to make you understand why he is the way he is, “I help when I can.”

“I know that kind of help,” I said, and I smiled like a person with a hammer smiles at a screw. “I’m working on the burning. It’s not a sermon, it’s a thing with elements. It might require a controlled setting. It will require patience no one has.”

He looked relieved in a way that made me sad for both of us. He set the pamphlet down as if it might explode under the wrong pressure. “We have a basement,” he said. “In case you ever need one.”

“I have a river,” I said, and he nodded, like a man who knows when he has been bested by myth.

After he left I locked the door not because I was afraid of him but because the room had changed shape and needed to be reminded of me. I took the mirror from under the bed and put it face-up on the table, the way you set a plate for someone you hope is in a mood to eat what you’re serving. I fetched the jars with their labels my mother taught me to write like penance. Basil. Parsley. Rust. Rain. I took the blue marble out and put it in a teacup because some things need a witness and some things need a cradle. I chalked my mark small in one corner and the triangle small in the other, then I drew a line between them that my hand wanted to be straight and my heart wanted to be crooked. Then I threaded a needle with hair and linen and a wire you cannot buy; you gather it from the hum refrigerators make when they think no one listens.

When I called for her, I didn’t say her name because people who know better told me not to. I said mine twice and then once more under my breath, which is how you take honesty and make it a dare. For a full minute the only movement was the slow storm inside the marble, rolling itself like dough. The mirror showed me myself until it didn’t. My face softened into a text you had to squint to read, then sharpened into a person who had my mouth but wore it like a borrowed thing.

“I was hoping you’d do this,” she said, and the mirror did a trick with depth that made me want to be sick on my own floor. Her coat—it was that green so specifically mine it put a heat under my tongue—was buttoned with impatience. She didn’t touch the glass because she didn’t need to. We both know how not to smudge if the thing that would get smudged is you.

“I keep a shop,” I said, because sometimes the only way to begin is with a sentence you know is true. “I keep a system. I keep my knees warm in winter. I keep the bins where the truck can get to them. Why do you keep lighting what I keep?”

“Because keeping isn’t saving,” she answered, and where I have comfort she has clarity, and that’s unfair, but the body never promised to divvy up the traits justly. “Because your keeping is a purse with a hole. You patch other people’s fabric with gold and blood, and then you come home with fingers that itch and your jaw tight as a trap, and you put everything of yours in the neatest boxes and none of it gets smaller. You ask the river to carry it and she’s tired, June. So I vault.”

“You’re making fire from restlessness,” I said, because we have both had the kind of lover you can’t take to meet your friends. “You’re burning the wrong thing to heat a room you don’t even go into.”

She tilted her head in that way I’ve seen in reflective windows when you think you’ve caught yourself and you haven’t. “You want a kiln,” she said, like a midwife naming a baby you didn’t think you could have. “You want to build one, and you want to feed it on purpose. Don’t lie to me. You like the truth too much to avoid the violent parts of it.”

“I want a boundary,” I said through my teeth. “I want a burn that isn’t a tantrum. I want to teach the heat to sing in key.”

“I am your fire,” she said mildly, like she was telling me what size shoes I wear. “I am the part of you that doesn’t sort, because sorting is a way to pretend that an ending can be domesticated. You called me when you looked at the bins and felt your own smallness like a bruise you keep pressing. You asked for a quick way. Quick ways are me.”

“I did not ask for a gull full of toys,” I said, and the mirror went mean around the edges, which is what happens when you say something the world takes personally. “I didn’t ask for a boy with burned plastic in his bag.”

“You asked for relief,” she said, not unkind now, which made me hate her a degree less and myself another degree extra. “You outsourced the heat. If you want it back, build me a mouth. If you want me gone, drown me. But you don’t get to pretend I’m not you. You don’t get to call me she and leave yourself clean.”

“How?” I asked, because I am so tired of metaphor even as I lace it into everything. “How do I build your mouth and not become a thing everyone will be sorry they tried to love?”

“You already know,” she said, looking down, and I followed her eyes because they are mine. The marble spun lightning. The storm pressed its face to the glass. The river had an opinion. “Repeat your work, but hotter. Stitch, but with flame. Solder, but with stricter mercy. Capture the breath. Trap the poison in a tile and make the babies walk on it without it walking into them. You want to save. Save by transformation. Save by admitting you like to change things. Stop lying that mending is gentle.” She smiled, and if you have never seen your own mouth smile at you when you do not want it to, I both recommend and do not recommend it. “Three days,” she said, conversational as weather. “On the fourth the wind will reverse. On the fourth I will do it without you.”

The mirror went back to being a river that had learned obedience reluctantly. My face returned. My hair looked like the aftermath of a summer thunderstorm. The marble settled into rain and stayed, as if it had been convinced by argument or lulled by exhaustion. I sat and fed myself the heel of yesterday’s bread with the care you give wild animals and thought about words like kiln and mouth and mouth that eats fire and spits glass. A plan is a spell with drawings; I made drawings with a pencil that had been used for meat and taxes and love notes and was therefore luckier than most.

The first person I told was Nate, because if anyone in this town knows how to look at a mountain that used to be a hill and decide where to put ropes, it’s the man who will climb it because he’s got to get the bottles out before they shift. He stood at the edge of the glass drop and chewed gum like it was the world’s fingers, then nodded in the slow rhythm of someone calculating weight. “We’ve got the old pizza oven Conklin tossed when the new one came with a touchscreen and a personality,” he said, eyes half-closed because the picture he was looking at wasn’t in front of him. “It’s ugly stainless, but it gets hot and holds it. We got ductwork nobody cries over if it smells like old pepperoni for the rest of its life. We’ll need scrap iron, and we’ll need to keep the witches who only read articles from showing up with signs. You promising me no plume?”

“I’m promising you capture,” I said, not because I like to promise but because some men, and some ovens, only agree to show up if you use the right verb. “I can net the breath. We’ll bind it to ceramic. It won’t like it, but it will hold.” I didn’t say tiles because tiles are for bathrooms and I was thinking about roads, about replacing asphalt with shame that held, about giving children hopscotch that keeps their lungs clear.

We welded. Welding is a kind of marriage if you’re not careful how you talk about it. Sparks made confetti and we pretended it was a holiday. We hauled the carcass of the oven under the lean-to and bolted it to a floor that has held up more weight than any of us will ever give it credit for. I climbed inside with a brush and a mouth full of prayer and painted the interior with a slurry I made from Etta’s ash, river mud, and the scraped grief off the bottom of Gideon’s boat. The slurry dried to a dull grey like we had invented a new species of rock that remembered hands. Nate looked like he wanted to call someone to come make us stop, and then he remembered there wasn’t anyone we trusted with that job. “You got a name?” he asked, as if the right name would make the dial willing to go to ten without blowing past.

“Retort,” I said, because Aunt Sable taught me that words are leashes and you choose the soft ones if you want something to follow you without bloodying your palms.

Eloise came with her clipboard and her hair pulled back so hard it changed her posture. She walked around the apparatus, tapping the metal with the butt of her pen because you don’t get to chair a meeting in this town if you don’t love the sound a machine makes when it pretends to be immune to your judgment. “If this fails,” she said, and left the sentence there, gesturing at a future full of meetings none of us wanted to sit through because every chair in City Hall is haunted by one resigned woman and one stubborn man.

“If this fails, I will move,” I said, blunt, because sometimes you need to give a friend a picture of the cliff you’re willing to walk over. “If it works, you will find a way to pay for the duct tape that doesn’t look like duct tape.”

She grunted, which I have decided is her way of agreeing when her hair is too tight to allow yes. “You’ll need permits,” she said, and then she signed the bottom of a paper and made the permits appear by reminding the universe who she is.

Gideon arrived last with a bucket of river stones the color of history. He ran his hands over the ducting like he was testing a horse, and the oven did not buck him because the oven is smart enough to know loyalty when it sees it. “You need ballast,” he said, handing me the chain he took off a retired anchor. “You need to tie it to something people already agree not to move.”

“What if it doesn’t want to stay?” I asked quietly, thinking of other things I had strung with intention only to find they preferred the edge.

“Then you tell it a story about what happens when the river runs backward,” he said. “It’ll listen.”

We fired the Retort with nothing in its mouth first, because even a hungry creature deserves a dry run. The oven glowed like a blush. Heat licked the ducts and went where it was supposed to go because Nate had promised to wring its neck if it tried any tricks. The capture jars—old demijohns I’d lined with the same slurry and wrapped in copper like fancy bottles who had married money—fogged and then cleared and then stayed clear, as if we had put a net over a song and learned to hum in harmony. Etta came in with a tray of scones that tasted like penance and triumph and stood with her fists on her hips like a saint who had criticized God and found Him open to notes. “When do you feed it?” she said, as one does when one has watched someone perfect their oven and is ready to put in bread.

“At night,” I said. “Not because it’s skulking. Because I want it to learn what darkness is for.”

We made a coat. I cut fire blankets into panels and stitched them with dull gold and thread I pulled from a rope, the kind of rope men have made and unmade their futures on. I lined it with foil that had once wrapped chocolates in a factory that wanted to pretend it was a cathedral, and I wrote sigils on the hems that said things like stay and things like consent. I tucked iron filings into the collar. I sewed my mark into the left wrist and left the right bare, because there should be a place for her to get out if she needs to remind me we make mistakes when we make prisons. This is the part no one sees when they come in for a button and a blessing and leave feeling lighter; the part where my teeth ache and my eyes go spiritless from looking at cloth until it becomes air. I bled on the sleeve and let it dry instead of washing it out like a good tailor. I want the garment to know whose blood makes its candor possible.

On the third day, the wind said the thing the mirror had promised. It changed direction without asking permission and brought with it a low note that made every bottle on the shelf in the back of my shop hum a sympathetic tune. The lake pressed its flat hand on the mouth of the river and said, go back. The river laughed the way a person laughs when you tell a joke that has sat too long in your pocket warming up on your leg: surprised and relieved in equal measure. Eloise texted me a weather map with an arrow and the word well. Gideon sent a picture of water shouldering itself up the wrong stair. Aunt Sable left a voicemail that was just a long exhale and then, at the end, “Don’t get in over your eyebrows, June-bug. Call me if you have to spit.”

I baited my trap like an honest liar. I filled a black bag with labels I had peeled and promises I had made and stuck all over my shirts like armor. I wrote on the outside in my neatest hand: Everything I am too tired to sort. I set it by the mouth of the Retort and left the door cracked like a lover. I unscrewed the bulb over the back door so the alley wouldn’t look like a stage. I put on the fire coat and felt heavier and safer and too warm and not warm enough. I tucked the marble in my pocket because the storm wanted to watch. I waited with my palms on the edge of the oven like it was a table I trusted with family recipes.

She came without drama. She came like a woman who has been doing night work for years and knows doors by their creak and steps that don’t rat out your presence. She put her hand on the bag and then on the oven and then she looked up like she had been hearing my voice for days and finally decided to stand where the sound was. I opened my mouth and told her the truth first, because I am superstitious about beginnings, because lies are mean if you let them start things. “I want to keep you,” I said. “Not like a coin in a pocket. Like a language. Like a stove you ask to make soup and it doesn’t catch the curtains. I want to give you a job you can live with.”

She tilted her head, measuring me against herself, measuring the oven against her hand’s memory of flame. “What if your city loves me more for the spectacle?” she asked, with a vanity I have earned and not enjoyed.

“Then I will ruin your spectacle with usefulness until even the men who love a problem for the way it makes their faces look cannot deny you improved their air,” I said, and the coat made a tiny sound when I breathed that told me I was wearing a promise I might not yet have the credit for.

The wind shoved, and the river, stubborn as family, shoved back. The water at the quick-pour under the bridge tried to climb and then got tired and swallowed. The air tasted metallic; you never forget that taste when you have dragged a thunderstorm inside to meet your mother. She put her hands into the sleeves I held out and the coat took her like a story takes a listener who was ready all along. The iron filings murmured the names of tools. The foil whispered about candy. The gold thread sang low. She hissed when the hem touched her calves, not with pain, but with recognition.

“Three nights,” she said again, but there was relief in it now, and a little threat, the way you tell a child it is bedtime even though the child put themselves to sleep on the floor an hour ago.

“We have tonight,” I said. “And then the river will make its decision about direction. You said fourth; I’m using the third.” I opened the Retort’s mouth and it breathed in a way that made the hairs on my neck consider retreating to another head. I put the bag in. I put my hand on her back like you would on the ribcage of a horse, and we sent it through together. The heat rose, but it didn’t claw. The ducts stayed quiet, but not silent. The capture bottles fogged, cleared, held. The slurry smelled like old sugar and boundary. The triangle drawn on the oven door with grease smudged and slipped and then failed to hold shape. The coat brightened along the seams as if someone inside had remembered how to be seen without being caught.

We stood like that, two women leaning on a machine, any picture of a future that wants to get better needing too many hands to keep its shape. When the first tile fell from the mold, it made a sound like coins, like rain hard enough to wash even the stubborn corners. It was ugly in the way that newborn things are ugly before you bathe them and kiss them and teach them to do anything but eat. I pried it up with a flat iron and held it between fingers ready for blisters. It was a green the lake sometimes is when it has been arguing with the sun all afternoon. It held a triangle caught in a net of my mark, and for a second that might have been a year I thought about all the floors I could make.

She leaned her head on my shoulder and we were the same height because of course we are. She smelled like burnt sugar and riverside weeds and fear I’ve almost learned to love. Outside, the river snapped and went the wrong way like a laugh that turns into a sob and then finds itself made of both. The streetlights shifted their reflections. The gulls panicked, then decided this too was a miracle they could shove their bodies around. Somewhere uptown, a man opened his door and told his dog this was weather and the dog believed him. Etta texted me a picture of a pot of chili because she cannot watch and not feed. Aunt Sable sent me a message with three words—Do. Not. Blink.—and it made me laugh, which was the same as crying, which was the same as deciding we could have one night of stranger tides and not be ruined.

We fed the Retort until the edges of my vision went soft and came back. We stacked the tiles like city planning. We watched the capture jars cloud and clear, cloud and clear, and every time the breath didn’t escape my lungs unclenched a little more. We did not speak much because some work is communion and some is a kind of court. When the oven coughed, we let it. When the coat cooled, I did not take it off her because the night had decided to be the kind of night that will use you for kindling if you let your skin show. We stood and watched the river pretend to be a different river and I thought: I will take her to the council with the coat on and let them look. I will take a tile and set it on Eloise’s desk and tell her to step on it. I will hand one to Pastor Lennox and tell him to put it in his basement and learn the names for the parts of his furnace. I will ask the boy on Thirteenth if he wants to build a fox that runs on a better fire.

The Retort sighed when we closed her mouth for the night and it sounded like a woman who, after a week of cleaning up other people’s meals, has one put in front of her and decides to sit. The wind kept pushing. The river kept arguing. The street cats took cover in places they forgot to tell each other about. I turned to my other self and found that while I had been busy not blinking, she had taken half a step into me. It wasn’t dramatic. It was an inch and a question. I didn’t move away. The coat stitched light along her wrist where my mark lives, and I understood the only simple thing left to understand: the only way out of some habits is through. I think we slept standing up. I think the river carried us both in the same direction for once, even if it was the wrong one for a while. I think the gulls forgave us temporarily. I think tomorrow we will wake stiff and greedy for coffee and stubborn about hope. I think the tiles will cure overnight and my hands will remember the weight. I think I will show up to the meeting with ash under my nails and a new kind of evidence that wants to be touched and not just seen.

When dawn found us, it had trouble deciding where to put itself. That kind of confusion makes accidents, but it also makes inventions. I opened my door and the night fell out in a lump and the morning scooped it back because mornings are good at pretending they anticipated everything. The air had that washed-out taste after a storm when everything looks newly painted and most of it is just old and wet. We took the coat off and it was like peeling a label from a jar that will never be as clean as you want it. She stood in her green, then she took the sleeve and laid it over my arm like a bandage and I let her. “Two more,” she said, and I knew what the numbers meant. “Don’t humiliate me by making me useless. Nobody in this town deserves a saint.”

“I’ve never made one,” I said, and we both tried not to smile like we shared the joke that my mother did not teach me and the river did. We went inside and I made tea that tasted faintly of the slurry because I hadn’t washed the cup as well as a girl who lives alone is supposed to. We split a scone and it crumbled into a map that looked nothing like this town and everything like it. The Retort ticked as it cooled. The tiles clicked like teeth. The river ran backward again and then remembered itself and was forgiven. We cleaned our hands and the grey came off easy and not at all. I put the first tile in my bag and the second in my pocket and the third in the place where I keep my fear of being caught. I put on my boots and my patience and my plan. I called Gideon and he said, I’ll be there if it floods in the room like it always does. I called Eloise and she said, don’t give them anything they can call pretty without having to pay for it. I called Aunt Sable and she said, hush and listen, and in the hush I heard my mother say, that will do, June, and I didn’t cry because I needed my eyes to see if the flames stayed where we told them to live.Eloise drove the meeting like she drives everything, with her shoulders and with a refusal to let her hair move unless it has been consulted. City Hall smells like old paper and a lemon cleaner that no longer believes in lemons. People came because they had decided the best way to spend a Thursday was to dress themselves in certainty and throw it at each other until something stuck. I walked in with the tiles wrapped in a towel that had been a shirt of my mother’s when she thought she might be a woman who wore white. The weight in my bag was not enough to break a strap, but it was enough to change my gait from customer to witness.

The men who want the glass program gone had printed handouts with flames where glass bottles should be. Someone had photoshopped my sign into one of the images and made the needle in it a spear. Pastor Lennox sat in the back with his hands folded and his tie pin aimed like an argument. Etta commandeered a row with three women whose hands are always damp with dishwater and never tremble. Gideon stood by the window where he could see the river if it decided to come inside to listen. The boy from Thirteenth had found a corner to lean his fox against. It was unmistakable even unfinished: ten tails lifting like whispers, impossible and sure. The fox’s face was cleverly built from a plastic bin lid cut into confidence.

Eloise tapped her pen, then tapped the wood with the gavel because the room needed to be reminded that wood has opinions. “We are not here to ask if witches exist,” she said, and that was mercy and also a warning. “We are here to decide if we are going to pretend we can save money by throwing a kind of hope away.”

A man in a hat shaped like a decision raised his hand and didn’t wait for permission. “We cain’t have bins on fire,” he announced in a voice like a won argument. “It looks bad. It is bad.”

“It is,” I said, before anyone else could, because I am tired of letting the wrong people have the first true sentence. I walked to the front and the city clerk who hates women with bags pretended not to hate mine. I put a tile on the floor of the aisle. You could make a religion out of watching people decide whether or not they are willing to step on something when they do not know if it is a trap. I stepped first. It was cool with a warmth underneath, the way some people are in public. “We burned what would have been burned anyway,” I said, and a wave of incorrect understanding went through the room and broke. “No,” I amended, because I refuse to be adopted by their stories. “We burned what was going to be burned wrong, and we told it where to live afterward. Pick it up.”

Pastor Lennox rose without being called like we were in a service after all and lifted the tile as if it might have a pulse. The green had cured overnight into something that held the light in its teeth. The triangle was caught, line broken over my mark and then bent into new angles that didn’t remember being vicious. You could see the breath trapped in it if you knew breath has a shape when it is tired enough. He passed it to the man in the hat and the man did not want to hold it and he did anyway because people like him will never turn down an opportunity to prove they are not afraid of women’s work.

“What’s in it?” someone called, a woman with a baby in a carrier who was telling me she wanted to be told, not scared.

“Heat that would otherwise go wandering,” I said. “A little shame. Bits of conversations that were happening in alleys when we were asleep. There are chemicals too.” I glanced at Eloise and she gave me the go-ahead to be more exact. “We captured volatiles from polyethylene and a tantrum, and we tied them to ceramic with a slurry of ash and river. We made the breath honest. We’re measuring the capture with proper instruments borrowed from the college because I want numbers, not just poetry. Right now it’s a pilot that works in my alley and uses regret as fuel. I want it to be a line item.”

A cheer began, then remembered itself and turned into clapping that belongs to meetings. The man in the hat frowned like he had been asked to parent a nephew. “What happens when the witches move?” he demanded, which was a nicer version of, what happens when June leaves or fails us.

“Then you will have to love it enough that it stays,” I said, which is not how budgets work and also how they do. “Or you will hire a woman who knows how to stitch and how to heat without terror.”

Gideon raised a hand and the room let him interrupt because they have seen what he carries up the bank. “I have two boats,” he said. “If this program goes, I’ll have three. I’d rather have a kiln in a lean-to than another stretch of river tied to my stern.”

Pastor Lennox surprised me by coming forward. He set the tile on the edge of Eloise’s dais and then did something genuinely humble. He stepped on it. He put his weight down. He closed his eyes. When he opened them he said, “It sounds like nothing,” and I saw how hard he worked to make everything sound like God. “We can put one in the church basement where the furnace coughs in winter. We have a fan that pulls air from the street. Let us catch something and prove it to the stubborn.”

Eloise’s face did the math of how many ways she was going to be scolded for whatever came out of her mouth. “Motion to maintain glass and to fund a pilot capture for non-compliant combustion,” she said briskly, and the room murmured because she knows how to make things sound like they’ve already been passed. “Motion to not let the word witch be the reason we cut something that works.” She looked at me. “Motion to requisition that ugly pizza oven from our storeroom that no one could bring themselves to throw away because we are emotionally attached to our leftovers.”

“Second,” said Etta, because she will marry Eloise to her job over and over until one of them is allowed to rest. A councilman whose wife does not let him leave the house with a plastic straw voted no so loudly his neck vein flexed. Two men abstained because they had never been taught that choosing is a form of spellcasting. The yeses were not loud. They were enough. It is a kind of love to be enough.

After, a woman with a gull on her shirt came to me with her mouth set like a hospital. She had the sharp look of the newly bereft who have already forgiven you because it is easier to carry forgiveness than vengeance when you have to also carry groceries. “I saw the pictures,” she said, soft so the room would not decide to possess our conversation. “I saw what they put in its gut. I want to put one of those in my kitchen.” Her finger touched the tile and came away clean. “I want to stand on something that used to be a problem and have it feel like floor.”

“I’ll bring you one,” I promised, because there are things you only promise to women like that, and you keep them because otherwise the tiles are just pretty. “Put it by your door. You’ll feel the air change.”

Outside, the wind was still doing the thing where it tries on hats and forgets where it left the one it needed. The boy from Thirteenth waited for me with his fox. Up close the creature was a joy and a warning. He had cut tails from milk jugs that had held a hundred kinds of sweetness and no one remembers them once they’re empty. He had fused them to a backbone made from a ruined crate I recognized. In the center he had left a cavity the size of a beating. “It needs a heart,” he said, as if that were a normal thing to say in public.

I put my hand in my bag and my fingers knew which tile to find. It wasn’t perfect. Nothing perfect belongs in a creature that plans to move. I gave it to him flat across both hands so he knew it was a gift that asked him to decide. He took it like a boy who has been hungry too long takes a bowl he intends to wash afterward. He fitted it into the fox. The tails lifted like a choir considering their entrance. He smiled—not polite, not for me—the kind you cannot teach and want to protect anyway.

“Don’t let anyone make you make dolphins,” I said, and he laughed the way a kid laughs when you name a ghost he thought only he could see.

Back in the shop, the tiles looked like a stack of decisions. The Retort’s mouth, when I opened it, sighed me into the afternoon. We brought the capture jars to the college and made a professor cry by admitting magic and measurement have always been married and we’re just finally throwing them a dinner with witnesses. Nate came by with bolts and his grin and said he’d scrounge us a proper hood from a restaurant that had died quietly in August. He winked and left a bag of washers that a person far from here might call charms. People brought offerings: a length of copper pipe that had outlived three kitchens, a stack of bricks with names scratched in, a ceramic rooster whose owner claimed it woke up and crowed the morning she decided to leave her husband and therefore might give us one good loud warning when we needed it.

“Night Two,” she said at dusk without bothering the mirror, without making the hair on the back of my neck try to run. She stood in the doorway like a memory I’d been expecting and didn’t dread because I had given her a job. The coat waited on the hook with the patience of a garment that knows it has become a tool and a myth. When I helped her into it we didn’t look at each other’s eyes. The skin there is honest to a fault.

“What did you do when we were small?” I asked as we fed the bag we had collected at the transfer station into the Retort in two careful pieces, because sometimes the ritual is in not pretending you can swallow whole. “What did you burn for me that I could not stand to see disappear the slow way?”

Her mouth twitched. It wasn’t a smile; it was a muscle remembering practice. “The notes we wrote to boys before we learned how to want without apology,” she said first, and it made me weirdly fond of us. “The white gloves your mother insisted you wear to Aunt Sable’s church the three times she felt a failure for not giving you pews and thought she could mend it with lace. The photographs of the car. The final letter from your father’s one good week. The wrappers from the candy we ate on a dock the day we watched a boat go where it was not tied to go.” She slid a look at me because we both remember the scraping panic that comes when water refuses to play by the rules you admire. “I burned our shame when it got heavy. I burned our boredom because it was louder than prayer.”

I felt the coat lift at the shoulder like a breath. We watched the jars milk and then clear, and the calm that came into the room was not quiet. It was something like competence, which is rarer than peace and twice as holy. “You set the trash can behind the first apartment on fire,” I said after a while, the words coming out on a leash I had never tried to put on them before.

“I did,” she said, not proud and not sorry. “You were fourteen, and your mother had started sleeping on the couch because the bed had become a continent where each of you tried and failed not to colonize each other. You wanted everything fast. I obliged. Aunt Sable came with a bucket and a warning and a glamour to keep Mrs. Calabrese from stepping out onto her stoop and starting a decade’s worth of trouble with her mouth. She told me to get out of your legs unless I planned to teach you how to run. I left and I waited. You named me when you couldn’t sleep for the first time and syllabled the sound a bag makes when a match loves it. I like my name. Don’t take it if you don’t mean to wear it.”

The tile from that burn came out mean and beautiful. It had a vein of red in it like a vein in a wrist, and it embarrassed me to want it. I cooled it on the table that has held every mistake I’ve ever managed to recover into usefulness. I put my palm on it and felt the hum. It was not dangerous. It would be if I put it under a pillow. We stack our hums in foolish places.

The man the sunburned woman had called “he” tried to set the Retort on fire on Night Two because of course he did. Show any town a solution and it will cough up a person with a hobby of breaking tools. He came with a can of accelerant and a mask he bought because a forum told him masks make men impervious to consequence. He sloshed inexpertly and lit expertly and the flames did what flames know. They licked for edges. The coat hummed and pulled the heat into itself and laid it gently down like a child who has thrown up in the back seat and is ashamed. Gideon, who knows how to be in three places at once when water is involved, arrived with the smaller boat’s pump rigged to a barrel and turned the arc into a line that convinced the fire it owed us something. The Retort’s mouth yawned and took what it was offered. The capture jars clouded in outrage. The tiles stacked their usual steady clatter. The man ran because his mask told him the story of vanishing. Nate chased him halfway to the old tannery before remembering he’s built for lifting and swearing, not sprinting in the dark.

After we cleaned the scorch marks that the Retort had the decency to keep on its own skin, I sat on the floor with my back to the oven and my knees up. Fear is not a spell; it is a door you have to unlatch with hands that shake. “You built me a mouth,” she said, and that was a kind of apology and also a covenant. “I won’t keep going to alleys where I am uninvited. I like being asked. It reminds me I was a choice.”

“Stay,” I said, to practice for strangers. “Work. Do not confuse hunger with need.” We say this to babies because we are trying to raise ourselves.

On the morning of the third day the river pretended to be tired of tricks. It looked like any river again to anybody who has never had to stand on a bank and persuade it by name. Aunt Sable arrived without warning in a sweater the color of a bruise that is almost better. Her mouth looked like it had been set in the night and would not unscrew for anybody but me. She kissed my eyebrows and my cheekbones and the top of my head, which is what she does when she is counting what I have left. “You look thinner in the ways that matter,” she said, then put her hands on the Retort and hissed a little through her teeth like a smith greeting a friend. “She likes you. You feeding her regular? You letting her rest?”

“Yes,” I said, because I have my pride and because it was true. “He came with a can last night.”

“Honey,” she said, rolling her eyes in a circle that took in every bad idea a man has had within a hundred-mile radius, “they always do. You cannot fix making without breaking and you cannot make breaking honorable. You can only make it expensive.”

We took a tile to Pastor Lennox and I let him put it by the vent in the basement. He looked at me like a man looks at a woman right before he asks a question he knows is going to be a foolish one unless she decides to treat it kindly. “Do you pray when you work?” he ventured, trailing the P like he might need to apologize for it.

“I count,” I said, because that is the thing closest to true. “Stitches. Bolts. Breaths. I say names. I say yes. It does something to my mouth that prayer probably does to yours.” I left him with the tile and his basement smelling faintly of sugar that burned for a good reason.

Eloise met me on the steps with a paper bag and an expression like she had just kissed a victory and it had bitten her. “Do not let them make you a symbol,” she said, thrusting the bag into my hands without ceremony. “You cannot be eaten for breakfast and expected to come back for dinner.” I opened the bag and found six permits and a pair of gloves that fit and an orange I had not admitted to needing until it was in my palm.

“Night Three,” my other self said at dusk, flipping the coat off the hook with only the flourish I would have allowed myself if I were alone. We had two bags, because I had spent the afternoon at the transfer station pulling triangles like thorns from the edges of lids and telling promising shapes they were not invitations. The Retort took them the way a grandmother takes a plate from a girl who has learned how to feed her: not surprised, still grateful. The jars did their cloud-clear, which had become a metronome for a kind of music I did not want to dance to and could not stop hearing. Outside, the wind from the lake went sulky and tried to slip around the edges of buildings without being noticed. Heat has its rites, and so does cold.

We did not talk much. When the tiles came, the third night’s were different. They were veined with something that looked like writing. The marks were not mine. They were not the triangle’s. They were little rumors of letters that I will convince you one day are a script spoken by rivers when they are trying to teach steel to think. I stacked them carefully and then took one to the river, because I am not an idiot about payment. I set it on the bank and the water lapped it like a name. I let the river keep it. The tile slid under with a contentment I have never been able to give anything other than tea.

At the mirror after, I called her and she came and she looked like me without anything to do. It is not a flattering expression. “If we put you into a tile,” I said, hating myself for the thought even as I loved myself for being willing to have it, “would you stay where I put you until I asked again?”

She smiled, small and not for show. “If you trap me, you’ll spend the rest of your life carrying me around looking for a way to teach me without starving me,” she said. “I’d rather wear the coat and learn to eat like a person.
