The green had cured overnight into something that held the light in its teeth. The triangle was caught, line broken over my mark and then bent into new angles that didn’t remember being vicious. You could see the breath trapped in it if you knew breath has a shape when it is tired enough. He passed it to the man in the hat and the man did not want to hold it and he did anyway because people like him will never turn down an opportunity to prove they are not afraid of women’s work.

“What’s in it?” someone called, a woman with a baby in a carrier who was telling me she wanted to be told, not scared.

“Heat that would otherwise go wandering,” I said. “A little shame. Bits of conversations that were happening in alleys when we were asleep. There are chemicals too.” I glanced at Eloise and she gave me the go-ahead to be more exact. “We captured volatiles from polyethylene and a tantrum, and we tied them to ceramic with a slurry of ash and river. We made the breath honest. We’re measuring the capture with proper instruments borrowed from the college because I want numbers, not just poetry. Right now it’s a pilot that works in my alley and uses regret as fuel. I want it to be a line item.”

A cheer began, then remembered itself and turned into clapping that belongs to meetings. The man in the hat frowned like he had been asked to parent a nephew. “What happens when the witches move?” he demanded, which was a nicer version of, what happens when June leaves or fails us.

“Then you will have to love it enough that it stays,” I said, which is not how budgets work and also how they do. “Or you will hire a woman who knows how to stitch and how to heat without terror.”

Gideon raised a hand and the room let him interrupt because they have seen what he carries up the bank. “I have two boats,” he said. “If this program goes, I’ll have three. I’d rather have a kiln in a lean-to than another stretch of river tied to my stern.”

Pastor Lennox surprised me by coming forward. He set the tile on the edge of Eloise’s dais and then did something genuinely humble. He stepped on it. He put his weight down. He closed his eyes. When he opened them he said, “It sounds like nothing,” and I saw how hard he worked to make everything sound like God. “We can put one in the church basement where the furnace coughs in winter. We have a fan that pulls air from the street. Let us catch something and prove it to the stubborn.”

Eloise’s face did the math of how many ways she was going to be scolded for whatever came out of her mouth. “Motion to maintain glass and to fund a pilot capture for non-compliant combustion,” she said briskly, and the room murmured because she knows how to make things sound like they’ve already been passed. “Motion to not let the word witch be the reason we cut something that works.” She looked at me. “Motion to requisition that ugly pizza oven from our storeroom that no one could bring themselves to throw away because we are emotionally attached to our leftovers.”

“Second,” said Etta, because she will marry Eloise to her job over and over until one of them is allowed to rest. A councilman whose wife does not let him leave the house with a plastic straw voted no so loudly his neck vein flexed. Two men abstained because they had never been taught that choosing is a form of spellcasting. The yeses were not loud. They were enough. It is a kind of love to be enough.

After, a woman with a gull on her shirt came to me with her mouth set like a hospital. She had the sharp look of the newly bereft who have already forgiven you because it is easier to carry forgiveness than vengeance when you have to also carry groceries. “I saw the pictures,” she said, soft so the room would not decide to possess our conversation. “I saw what they put in its gut. I want to put one of those in my kitchen.” Her finger touched the tile and came away clean. “I want to stand on something that used to be a problem and have it feel like floor.”

“I’ll bring you one,” I promised, because there are things you only promise to women like that, and you keep them because otherwise the tiles are just pretty. “Put it by your door. You’ll feel the air change.”

Outside, the wind was still doing the thing where it tries on hats and forgets where it left the one it needed. The boy from Thirteenth waited for me with his fox. Up close the creature was a joy and a warning. He had cut tails from milk jugs that had held a hundred kinds of sweetness and no one remembers them once they’re empty. He had fused them to a backbone made from a ruined crate I recognized. In the center he had left a cavity the size of a beating. “It needs a heart,” he said, as if that were a normal thing to say in public.

I put my hand in my bag and my fingers knew which tile to find. It wasn’t perfect. Nothing perfect belongs in a creature that plans to move. I gave it to him flat across both hands so he knew it was a gift that asked him to decide. He took it like a boy who has been hungry too long takes a bowl he intends to wash afterward. He fitted it into the fox. The tails lifted like a choir considering their entrance. He smiled—not polite, not for me—the kind you cannot teach and want to protect anyway.

“Don’t let anyone make you make dolphins,” I said, and he laughed the way a kid laughs when you name a ghost he thought only he could see.

Back in the shop, the tiles looked like a stack of decisions. The Retort’s mouth, when I opened it, sighed me into the afternoon. We brought the capture jars to the college and made a professor cry by admitting magic and measurement have always been married and we’re just finally throwing them a dinner with witnesses. Nate came by with bolts and his grin and said he’d scrounge us a proper hood from a restaurant that had died quietly in August. He winked and left a bag of washers that a person far from here might call charms. People brought offerings: a length of copper pipe that had outlived three kitchens, a stack of bricks with names scratched in, a ceramic rooster whose owner claimed it woke up and crowed the morning she decided to leave her husband and therefore might give us one good loud warning when we needed it.

“Night Two,” she said at dusk without bothering the mirror, without making the hair on the back of my neck try to run. She stood in the doorway like a memory I’d been expecting and didn’t dread because I had given her a job. The coat waited on the hook with the patience of a garment that knows it has become a tool and a myth. When I helped her into it we didn’t look at each other’s eyes. The skin there is honest to a fault.

“What did you do when we were small?” I asked as we fed the bag we had collected at the transfer station into the Retort in two careful pieces, because sometimes the ritual is in not pretending you can swallow whole. “What did you burn for me that I could not stand to see disappear the slow way?”

Her mouth twitched. It wasn’t a smile; it was a muscle remembering practice. “The notes we wrote to boys before we learned how to want without apology,” she said first, and it made me weirdly fond of us. “The white gloves your mother insisted you wear to Aunt Sable’s church the three times she felt a failure for not giving you pews and thought she could mend it with lace. The photographs of the car. The final letter from your father’s one good week. The wrappers from the candy we ate on a dock the day we watched a boat go where it was not tied to go.” She slid a look at me because we both remember the scraping panic that comes when water refuses to play by the rules you admire. “I burned our shame when it got heavy. I burned our boredom because it was louder than prayer.”

I felt the coat lift at the shoulder like a breath. We watched the jars milk and then clear, and the calm that came into the room was not quiet. It was something like competence, which is rarer than peace and twice as holy. “You set the trash can behind the first apartment on fire,” I said after a while, the words coming out on a leash I had never tried to put on them before.

“I did,” she said, not proud and not sorry. “You were fourteen, and your mother had started sleeping on the couch because the bed had become a continent where each of you tried and failed not to colonize each other. You wanted everything fast. I obliged. Aunt Sable came with a bucket and a warning and a glamour to keep Mrs. Calabrese from stepping out onto her stoop and starting a decade’s worth of trouble with her mouth. She told me to get out of your legs unless I planned to teach you how to run. I left and I waited. You named me when you couldn’t sleep for the first time and syllabled the sound a bag makes when a match loves it. I like my name. Don’t take it if you don’t mean to wear it.”

The tile from that burn came out mean and beautiful. It had a vein of red in it like a vein in a wrist, and it embarrassed me to want it. I cooled it on the table that has held every mistake I’ve ever managed to recover into usefulness. I put my palm on it and felt the hum. It was not dangerous. It would be if I put it under a pillow. We stack our hums in foolish places.

The man the sunburned woman had called “he” tried to set the Retort on fire on Night Two because of course he did. Show any town a solution and it will cough up a person with a hobby of breaking tools. He came with a can of accelerant and a mask he bought because a forum told him masks make men impervious to consequence. He sloshed inexpertly and lit expertly and the flames did what flames know. They licked for edges. The coat hummed and pulled the heat into itself and laid it gently down like a child who has thrown up in the back seat and is ashamed. Gideon, who knows how to be in three places at once when water is involved, arrived with the smaller boat’s pump rigged to a barrel and turned the arc into a line that convinced the fire it owed us something. The Retort’s mouth yawned and took what it was offered. The capture jars clouded in outrage. The tiles stacked their usual steady clatter. The man ran because his mask told him the story of vanishing. Nate chased him halfway to the old tannery before remembering he’s built for lifting and swearing, not sprinting in the dark.

After we cleaned the scorch marks that the Retort had the decency to keep on its own skin, I sat on the floor with my back to the oven and my knees up. Fear is not a spell; it is a door you have to unlatch with hands that shake. “You built me a mouth,” she said, and that was a kind of apology and also a covenant. “I won’t keep going to alleys where I am uninvited. I like being asked. It reminds me I was a choice.”

“Stay,” I said, to practice for strangers. “Work. Do not confuse hunger with need.” We say this to babies because we are trying to raise ourselves.

On the morning of the third day the river pretended to be tired of tricks. It looked like any river again to anybody who has never had to stand on a bank and persuade it by name. Aunt Sable arrived without warning in a sweater the color of a bruise that is almost better. Her mouth looked like it had been set in the night and would not unscrew for anybody but me. She kissed my eyebrows and my cheekbones and the top of my head, which is what she does when she is counting what I have left. “You look thinner in the ways that matter,” she said, then put her hands on the Retort and hissed a little through her teeth like a smith greeting a friend. “She likes you. You feeding her regular? You letting her rest?”

“Yes,” I said, because I have my pride and because it was true. “He came with a can last night.”

“Honey,” she said, rolling her eyes in a circle that took in every bad idea a man has had within a hundred-mile radius, “they always do. You cannot fix making without breaking and you cannot make breaking honorable. You can only make it expensive.”

We took a tile to Pastor Lennox and I let him put it by the vent in the basement. He looked at me like a man looks at a woman right before he asks a question he knows is going to be a foolish one unless she decides to treat it kindly. “Do you pray when you work?” he ventured, trailing the P like he might need to apologize for it.

“I count,” I said, because that is the thing closest to true. “Stitches. Bolts. Breaths. I say names. I say yes. It does something to my mouth that prayer probably does to yours.” I left him with the tile and his basement smelling faintly of sugar that burned for a good reason.

Eloise met me on the steps with a paper bag and an expression like she had just kissed a victory and it had bitten her. “Do not let them make you a symbol,” she said, thrusting the bag into my hands without ceremony. “You cannot be eaten for breakfast and expected to come back for dinner.” I opened the bag and found six permits and a pair of gloves that fit and an orange I had not admitted to needing until it was in my palm.

“Night Three,” my other self said at dusk, flipping the coat off the hook with only the flourish I would have allowed myself if I were alone. We had two bags, because I had spent the afternoon at the transfer station pulling triangles like thorns from the edges of lids and telling promising shapes they were not invitations. The Retort took them the way a grandmother takes a plate from a girl who has learned how to feed her: not surprised, still grateful. The jars did their cloud-clear, which had become a metronome for a kind of music I did not want to dance to and could not stop hearing. Outside, the wind from the lake went sulky and tried to slip around the edges of buildings without being noticed. Heat has its rites, and so does cold.

We did not talk much. When the tiles came, the third night’s were different. They were veined with something that looked like writing. The marks were not mine. They were not the triangle’s. They were little rumors of letters that I will convince you one day are a script spoken by rivers when they are trying to teach steel to think. I stacked them carefully and then took one to the river, because I am not an idiot about payment. I set it on the bank and the water lapped it like a name. I let the river keep it. The tile slid under with a contentment I have never been able to give anything other than tea.

At the mirror after, I called her and she came and she looked like me without anything to do. It is not a flattering expression. “If we put you into a tile,” I said, hating myself for the thought even as I loved myself for being willing to have it, “would you stay where I put you until I asked again?”

She smiled, small and not for show. “If you trap me, you’ll spend the rest of your life carrying me around looking for a way to teach me without starving me,” she said. “I’d rather wear the coat and learn to eat like a person. That is your vanity talking when it asks for artifact. Keep a piece of me in a pocket if it helps you sleep. Let the rest stay in the part of your mouth that makes yes. Don’t put me behind glass.”

We did not leave each other that night because there are nights when leaving is silly theater and there are nights when leaving is necessary. We slept in shifts, stretched in the coat, with the Retort ticking like a polite animal. At dawn I carried tiles around town like a green Mary handing out a sacrament nobody has agreed on yet. I put one in the co-op by the compost bins. I put one under the counter at Conklin’s where the new oven huffs like a dog with a grudge. I left one for the woman with the gull shirt and she sent me a photograph of the square by her door with the caption, it looks like a lake, and a second message that made my lungs widen: it feels like opening my window.

The boy from Thirteenth came in without knocking because I had told him to stop knocking. He held the fox. He had given it eyes made from the bottoms of bottles I had seen on my own sill last spring. He had put the tile-heart in and sealed it with copper wire braided into nerve. “It runs,” he said, breathless the way boys pretend not to be, and he set it down and it did. It did not move in a way that makes science happy. It moved the way you feel a thing in your peripheral, and if you turn to look at it properly it firmly refuses to be caught doing anything that could get it in trouble. It made a sound like a kettle that knows better. He looked at me and tried to play bored and then couldn’t. “They asked me for dolphins again,” he said, rolling his eyes so big you could take a small boat into them.

“Say no,” I said, and then, because that is not as easy as it comes out of my mouth, I reached under the counter and gave him a roll of wire and a pair of pliers that had belonged to my grandfather and are the closest thing I own to a blessing. “When you have told them no enough times, make the thing that refuses to be a compromise. Then go to the river and ask it to mind your tails when you’re asleep.”

He hefted the pliers like a boy hefts a responsibility. “You want your tile back when I’m done?” he asked, manners winning out over art for a second.

“Let it run on,” I said, and he grinned with his whole face and fled because boys know when to leave before you change your mind and give them rules they will enjoy breaking and also apologize for.

The man with the accelerant was arrested because he had posted footage of his own crimes with captions that suggested he thought arson is a form of commentary when it is only a form of cowardice. Eloise told me this in a message that did not enjoy delivering satisfaction. She added: strings were pulled. I wrote back: who holds the other end, and she sent me a photograph of a hand I know I will recognize if it ever passes me a bowl at a potluck. The city is small. There are not that many hands. You always know whose hands are doing the breaking.

Night Three ended, but the heat did not go away. Heat never goes away. It moves its chair. It learns new names. It gets a job. I put the coat on the hook and the hook bent a fraction and then straightened as if it was willing to be stronger for us. She and I stood in the kitchen. We looked at the jars and the tiles and the list I had written without admitting I had written it—places that need one, people who will use them, a corner in my own shop where the air goes stale. “Do we braid?” I asked, because sometimes you are brave enough to ask the question your aunt warned you lies under other questions like a river under a street.

“Not yet,” she said, with a kindness that relieved and annoyed. “You are not done liking me separate.”

“Will we always clean up in the night?” I pressed, thinking of women who age into the kind of tired that doesn’t squeak anymore.

“If we are lucky,” she said. “If we are not, we will tend fires we did not build for people who do not say that we did. Either way, we will get very good at sleeping on our feet.”

On the morning the river remembered itself entirely and stopped playing the backward game, the council brought cameras. Eloise told them to aim at the tiles and at the duct and not at my face more than they needed to. Pastor Lennox quoted a verse about furnace and proof and did not make it about me, which I marked down as growth for both of us. Etta brought donuts iced the color of lake-glass and set them in a neat row that said: look how delicious sustainable can be. Gideon stood with one hand on the ducting as if the city were a boat that might untie itself and drift. The boy with the fox came because he likes to be where grown-ups pretend to know what to do next. Aunt Sable wore a dress with anchors and a smile like, if anybody calls this a miracle in my hearing I will make sure they are put to work.

We fired the Retort for demonstration, but I kept the burn small because the only thing better than spectacle is refusal. It glowed, but not spectacularly. It breathed, but not dramatically. The capture jars did their trick and then were just glass again, empty and suggestive. The tile we pulled was ordinary. I wanted them to see the fact that ordinary can be savior. Eloise spoke in that way she has that makes it sound like we are all in a choir and suddenly found our note. “We will pilot. We will measure. We will not cut glass,” she said, leaning on the gavel hand the way she does when she thinks she might cry and would rather break the table.

After, a girl who works in the library in the afternoons and reads tarot in her kitchen at night came to me with a book on kilns she had nicked out of the discard pile. It had been stamped withdrawn in the tidy grief of librarians. “I thought you might like to keep it,” she said. “They were going to pulp it.”

“I hate pulping,” I said, turning the pages and feeling the comfort of diagrams that believe if you follow instructions you can hold fire without apology. “They always think it’s mercy.”

The wind laid down. The river curled around its own ankle and looked up, seductive again instead of churlish. I took a tile to the Nestlé grounds and laid it at the foot of a wall that had held back sweetness for too long. I chalked a new sentence under the old chalk: we are the same only to the degree that we forgive the ways we aren’t. I rubbed it with my sleeve and let the brick decide how much to keep. I went home and sorted. Clear to clear. Brown to brown. Green into green. Plastics into the bag I will not put to flame unless I am wearing the coat and the river has been told and the duct is happy. Metal, paper, cardboard cut down to rectangles that stack like a version of my hope. My hands still smelled like sugar that went hard and then learned to be useful. My breath fogged the glass enough to write on it with my finger. I wrote my name. I wrote hers. I wiped both off with the heel of my hand and watched the river through the smear and thought, I will build a floor out of our worst and then I will dance on it until the tired in this city learns to be proud.

After the cameras, after the palms smudged with tile dust, after the carefully neutral interview in which I said words like pilot and community and not once said spell, the town exhaled the kind of breath people let go when they think they have gotten away with something good. It wasn’t relief; relief has a softness the wind did not grant us. It was a recalibration. In my pocket the marble pressed at my hip in slow circles as if the weather inside it had been taught to dance a box step. I opened Stitch & Solder to the cautious bell of the afternoon and stood for a long moment with both hands on the counter, feeling the leftover heat in the wood, the extra heartbeat thin work gives it. If I had been a different kind of woman I would have written down the day on an index card and filed it under proof, to be pulled out later when doubt got clever. I have never managed to keep files outside my own ribs.

The first visitor after the spectacle smelled like lake wind trapped in a car. She had state in the cut of her jacket and DEC on a small enamel pin that had been chosen by someone who thought plants and letters shared a joke. She introduced herself as Delia Mott and didn’t offer a hand. I can forgive that in winter and in women who are more used to touching water than skin.

“I saw the jars,” she said. She had a face that had grown allergic to adjectives. “I saw the test numbers the college sent over. I don’t like your words for it, but I don’t mind that you have them.”

“You don’t have to like my words,” I said. “You can have your own and we can point them at each other like flashlights and see if the same corners get lit.”

A corner of her mouth considered becoming a smile and thought better of it. She took out a small device that looked like the descendant of a compass and a toy. “You’re going to have a bale fire,” she said, in the tone of a woman warning a friend about a tendency with a name. “Not because of the rumor kids. Because of physics and carelessness. The stacks at the station have been going up in the region. Once one takes, it burns like a book you thought wouldn’t keep your attention. Hours. Sometimes days. Plastics throw tantrums when you gang them up and squeeze the air out, and when they go it’s a dragon you don’t get to befriend. You try to smother, it sulks and burns deeper. Water makes it mad. Foam drowns dollars and pride. If you’re going to keep your mouth, you’ll need to teach it to eat big.”

“I have a Retort,” I said, refusing to apologize to her invisible colleagues for capitalization. “I have ducting. I have a coat that can withstand more heat than I like admitting fits my shoulders. I have a city with too many hands and not enough patience. I have—” I didn’t mean to say I have her, but the sentence tilted and there she was anyway, my other self shifting inside me in the way a cat shifts behind a curtain and you’re aware of both the moving and the choice to let it remain unseen. I did not flinch. “—help.”

Delia looked at me the way the river looks at a new dock. “You’ll have resistance,” she said, a little tired now, like a woman who has had too many meetings about ash. “You’ll have someone tell you that your jars are masquerade. You’ll have a man say he knows what fire wants because he has a grill and an opinion. You’ll have to decide whether your coat makes you a firefighter or a hazard. The forms aren’t made for you.”

“I’ve never looked at a form and thought it was,” I said. “But I can hold a pen. I can wait. I can show up where the fire is doing its worst and turn its mouth toward work.”

She tilted the device at my shelves and it clicked as if it had found a toy it would later complain about having to share. “I hate that magic gets there before money,” she said flat, and there was a kindness in it truer than any of the compliments I had been handed that morning like cheap mints. “Call me when the bale goes.”

She left me her card with a number written in pencil on the back, which is how serious women tell you where they will really be. When she left, the bell protested as if it didn’t like being asked to chime twice so close together. I put the card on the mirror and the mirror considered it and then, with the polite vanity reflective surfaces possess, returned my face with two expressions: the one that believes in permits, and the one that burns them.

We had one full night with no crisis and I used it improperly. I should have slept. I made more of the coat instead. Not another whole; I am not so hubristic as to think I could duplicate the way the first one learned my breath. I made cuffs that I could hand to other people so they could steady a pipe without losing their skin. I stitched a cap for Nate, against his insistence that he has never been burned in his life. I lined the insides with my dull gold and my superstition. Aunt Sable sat at my table and pretended not to supervise while she picked parsley heads into a bowl and told me about the kind of forecasters who develop crushes on storms.

“You’re mother loved a ruin,” she said suddenly, the parsley scent brighter for being recalled. “It made her feel braver. Don’t repeat her bravest part. Pick another.”

“What would you have me pick?” I asked, not irritated, exactly, but aware that I was a tendon away from it.

“Pick staying,” she said, as if she were asking me to pass the salt. “Pick boring. Pick the kind of magic that takes longer than anyone in a loud hat thinks they have.”

We were almost done with the cuffs when Gideon knocked twice in a pattern he has agreed not to change on me. His hat was under his arm and his hair did that thing like it had argued with spray and lost. He looked older than yesterday and younger than last year, which meant something had been found and something had been spared. “It’s started,” he said. “Not the bale yet. Not there. Out by the field behind the old tannery. Plastic and leaves, which is a combination invented by a person who has never asked a fire what it wants to eat. Somebody took a picture and somebody else took a match. I tamped it with shovels and a boy, but it’s crawling under like a secret. It’ll find a stump and then we’ll be sorry.”

I put down the cuff and picked up the coat. I wanted to have a ritual. I wanted to kiss the doorway, murmur to the jars, touch my mother’s scissors with the back of my hand. I didn’t. I tied my boots. I put the marble in my pocket so that when I put my hand there later looking for courage I would find weather instead. Sable caught my sleeve with two fingers. “You do not go looking for the girl when you are tired,” she said. “You let her come to you when you’ve already lit the stove and set the table. She behaves better when she feels expected.”

The night over the field was the color of the underside of a dog’s ear. You want to call it brown and you’re wrong; there’s more to it than that. You could hear the fire before you saw it. Low. Insulted. The pile itself wasn’t large—two yard bags loosed and a drift of leaves up against the chainlink, bottles and a broken tote, bits of plastic lawn edger that wanted to pretend they were snakes. But someone had laced the bags with something that made the flames talk in a way I recognized. The triangle had been drawn on the side of a half barrel. It looked tired of itself.

We did not perform. Gideon didn’t add water. He shouldered the pump anyway because that is his way of not admitting he knows when he isn’t needed. I shrugged the coat on and felt the heat hesitate like a sentence in a mouth that has learned the word if. I opened the Retort in my mind because the lean-to was too far and the duct was asleep. I have stitched enough to know that sometimes the tool is what you have where you are. I cupped my hands and made the kind of mouth you teach to a child when you teach them how to blow out a candle without spitting wax everywhere. She took my elbows; we both breathed.

It is not beautiful work. The smell fought back, sweet and ugly. The plastic shrieked in whatever register shame hums in. My hands shook with the effort of telling heat who is older. The air bent and the cool underlayer slipped forward. I felt the coat take it and slow it and send it where the jars in my head had been set. It occurred to me that I was being watched and should straighten my back; I did not. I made my back round around the burn and let the night make its own judgments. Gideon stood where men stand when they have been instructed by women without noticing. He did not speak. He adjusted the pump’s intake like a person adjusting a halo they didn’t agree to.

When it was done, when the pile had become the kind of ash that contains both apology and potential regret, I chalked a small circle over the triangle on the barrel and the chalk found purchase on the soot like chalk always does. I drew my stitch over it and the line broke the line and something in me eased. On the ground, embedded in the dregs of the bag, a piece of plastic had fused into a shape you could mistake for a fish if you wanted to. I did not want to. I put it in my pocket and the marble sulked because it does not like company it did not choose.

“Who?” Gideon said, which meant: am I going to have to go to anyone’s mother in the morning with my face arranged.

“Not kids,” I said. “But not men either. Someone doing a ritual too careful for a teenage dare and too messy for a professional. Someone who read half a forum and none of a book. Someone who blew on a coal and liked the sound their own breath made.”

He nodded as if I had handed him a location. “The bales are stacked like graves,” he said. “They’re dry under where the tarp doesn’t reach. One spark. I told Nate to sit on them. He said he would. He won’t.”

He was right on both counts. The call came when the moon had been up long enough to make men ridiculous. I picked up the phone and I knew it before it spoke. The sound behind Nate’s voice was the low hum of something that intends to be a roar. You can tell by the way it refuses to issue apologies on your timeline. “It’s taken,” he said, and his gum snapped once in the middle of the sentence like punctuation. “Middle of the stack, front left, next to the pallet with the bent nail. I got it isolated and I got cones and I got a kid with common sense standing in the road waving cars off. I don’t have time.”

“On my way,” I said, and put the coat on as if it were an argument I had been waiting my whole life to have. I did not put a hat on, because sometimes you have to let your scalp feel the weather or it will take its revenge in a less convenient circumstance. I texted Delia Mott and didn’t wait for dots. I texted Eloise and didn’t apologize. I told Aunt Sable to pretend I had not told her anything, and she hissed down the line with the tenderness of a kettle.

When you see a bale fire for the first time you think very unkind thoughts about anyone who has ever used the word manageable in a meeting. They had put the stacks in neat rows as if neatness could teach vice lessons. The fire had found the seam in the front and it had chewed inward with the same patience I have for hems. The outward face looked ordinary—flames flowered, smoke insisted—and then the bale split and the belly of it glowed a terrible cherry, and I understood why you do not put your hands in the thing you have made, even if you love it. The air above it was a muscle flexed wrong. Nate stood with a hook and his cap and a face that said: I have been taller than most problems and this one has decided not to be impressed.

“Don’t drown it,” Delia said, coming up on my right with her device clipped to her jacket like a brooch that knows things. Her breath looked like mine in the cold. “If you drown it, it sulks and eats back. You have to give it a way out and stop the out from going into our air. It’s an insult,” she added, high enough for the fire to hear, “that it gets agreeable once it’s been given a purpose.”

“Insults I can handle,” I said, and then louder, because the blaze knew my voice and I was not going to pretend otherwise. “You liked the coat. You liked the mouth. You liked being aimed. Here is a feast. Do not disgrace yourself.”

We made a maw out of ugly things. Nate had a roll-off bin at the back, half full of things that can handle heat and things that pretend they can until they forget themselves. We tipped it empty with a racket to wake the men on the other side of town who pretend to hate witches and secretly get bored when nothing is on fire. Delia rigged a fan from the back of her truck and said nothing about the law. I tugged ducting into place with Gideon anchoring chain to the corner of the bale and did not think about how much of my life is literally duct tape and faith. We made the Retort’s mouth at a distance, a cousin, an improvisation I would have laughed at in another chapter. I turned the capture jars into an array and pretended they were pretty on purpose. The coat sang under my hands, which is not a thing I admit to often and may not admit to again.

She came without being called separately. There are nights when I go looking for her; there are nights when she goes where fire is because our agreement was never about ownership. She slipped into the coat like the coat had missed her. She held the seam at the back of the makeshift duct with one hand and put the other on the bale, not on the flame but on the place heat makes in the air. The triangle had been painted on the pallet and then bled up into the wood like a fever dreaming of symbols. She looked at me and I drew my stitch over it in the air, and if anyone ever tries to tell you that gesture means nothing, send them to my alley and I will teach their bones to feel otherwise.

The first pull was easy. Fire loves to be asked. The second was insulted; we had tricked it into working. It tried to throw its smoke into our lungs and found the coat between us. The jars fogged and only one failed, out of six, which felt like a sin I could ask to be allowed to make again. Nate put the cap on the failed one with a hand steady enough to clip a bishop. Delia’s device chattered and heeded her; she adjusted the fan with two fingers and the air changed by a degree you would miss if your blood didn’t know. Gideon rigged the boat pump into a push and created a draft the bale could not argue with. The fire went under. It went up. It went where we told it to go. It behaved like a thing that had been given a chore with consequences and praise attached.

On the third pull I saw the thing I didn’t want to see and the town will never know it almost cost them me. In the heart of the bale, lodged like a penny under a tongue, there was a toy car melted into a melt. It wasn’t anything; it was a dollar store red with racing decals. It had caught and fused and seemed to grieve itself. It had the same make as the car my father had driven. That’s all. That’s nothing. That’s everything, when you are already hot and your memory keeps rolled photographs in a drawer you do not always keep locked. The coat drew what was mine to draw and she reached out and put her hand, my hand, on my wrist where the mark sits. She squeezed once like a woman acknowledging that sometimes the burn is not chemistry. I turned my face away from the toy. The air filled my mouth and I did not die on it.

Delia pointed at the pallet and I saw how the triangle had been made with a stencil, not a hand. It had been repeated with precision where there had been none anywhere else. The runes that frightened Eloise had a source you could clean. I chalked over it again, stitch and stitch, not because chalk can undo unreasonable men but because chalk is cheap and marks walls well. Nate muttered, “I’ll find who brings these boards and they will forget where they keep their lighter,” and I did not tell him that vengeance is best spent on tools. I let him have it. He needed a job.

We pulled and we pulled and we stacked tiles on a pallet that had never asked to be better. The green in them was deeper than the morning’s and the veins told a different story, a longer sentence about patience and irritation and the grace of not letting a thing you did once for spectacle turn into a habit. The firefighters came late not because they are lazy but because this town is held together with too few men in hats and too many fires. They stared and then they pretended they were not impressed and then one of them took a cuff and said, “If you have seven of these I will never again have to explain to a rookie why their eyebrows hurt,” and I said, “Come by the shop when your hands are clean.”

When the bale was over, when the heat had become agreeable to the degree that makes it almost not itself, the boy from Thirteenth appeared like a fox who had been told there were eggs and had come to check even if you had not told him gently. He had the sculpture, the tails lifted like flags in disdain of the hour. He had stitched scraps of the old municipal tarp into flanks and he had riveted pieces of hard plastic into tendons. The tile-heart glowed dull and dignified in its chest. He set the fox down near the stack and it shivered like fire does when it has been convinced to remember it can be light without showing off. He didn’t speak. He looked at the men in hats like he knew they had names they never tell anyone because those names are tender. He looked at me as if he had promised himself a future that required me to be alive.

“You going to put one of those green squares in my garage?” Nate asked, which was as close to admiration as he is structured to be.

“I’m going to put one in the bottom of the duct you haven’t had time to fix for three months,” I said, sweet as chili. “And then I’m going to invoice you a number so small you will be insulted and try to pay more, and then you will take me out to the brownfield and show me where the fence has been cut twice and you will pretend you didn’t see it until I saw it.”

“Deal,” he said with dignity. He deserves a church for his dignity. He will never get one.

Delia put a hand on my arm that felt like approval disguised as warning. “If you’re going to scale this,” she said, the we on her tongue and the policy in her shoulder, “you will need more jars, more hands, and fewer speeches. You will make enemies that are boring. Bureaucracy isn’t a dragon you can charm. It’s a fungus. You like fungi? You have to if you plan to stay.”

“I am excellent at fungi,” I said. “I live in old buildings.”

We stood there in our coats not admiring the sheen the fire had left on the night. The bale hissed when it found a wet bit and then stopped when it realized we weren’t going to let it use the sound to distract us. Someone drove by and yelled something about witches that could have, in a good translation, meant thank you. The fox tilted its ten tails toward me and I put my hand on its head and it sank a fraction into the weight of me, like it had agreed to live in my city as long as we fed it the right kind of fire.

After, after the after, when I had gone home and set the coat on the hook and my hands were steady again for almost three whole minutes, I took the fused fish out of my pocket and set it on the mirror. It looked cheap and shameful and I wanted to throw it into the deepest part of the river and dare the gulls to carry it back. The mirror made it into something else—not prettier, and not excused. It made it into a lesson with a shape that could be taught. She stood behind me in the glass and we did not banter because we had both had enough of audiences. We stood like women in a kitchen after a wake, holding each other’s elbows, telling each other with our bones that we have to eat in the morning and not eat fire.

The days that followed were busy in the way falls are busy when you’ve dammed a creek for years and then give it a sluice. Tiles went out and not all of them came home to be cured on my table; people took them and thought to warm them on their own radiators and learned what happens when you try to rush a spell like you rush a stew. I replaced two with a smile and a lecture and one with a soft scold that made a woman cry in a way that made me leave her a cookie under the tile when I delivered it. Pastor Lennox put one by the furnace vent in the church basement and then on Sunday said nothing about it from the pulpit and that silence did a strange good. Eloise told me that there was a man in a long thread who had read three scientific abstracts about combustion and planned to use them to scold me in public; she printed the abstracts, highlighted the parts he would misuse, and carried them in her purse like a war prayer. Nate found the pallets with the triangle stencil and we followed them back to a lot where a man with a flag affixed to his truck in a way that hurt flag and truck both was willing to hold a match in front of us and ask if we felt safer. He did not meet my eyes when I stepped past him and drew chalk on his tailgate like a woman teaching a dog not to bark in the night.

Some of the plastic cult, if they were that and not just a noise with hands, lost interest because we made it unglamorous. Some stuck around and carved sloppy triangles into snowbanks and plastic picnic tables and men’s bathroom stalls, and the portion of my soul that got good at ignoring graffiti at sixteen put on work boots and kept working. Two boys came by the shop with cheeks pink from choosing that hour of night to be outside, and they put down a sack full of cigarette butts like they were paying tithes. “We don’t smoke,” one said defensively. “We just pick up.”

“You can do both,” I said, handing them a tile they could take home to their mother as evidence of what they had been doing instead of what she thought. “But if you do both I will make you scrub my back alley with a toothbrush until you grow old.”

They grinned with that particular seam of malice that lives next to sweetness in adolescents and that fuels revolutions when we manage to aim it correctly. The boy with the fox brought me a drawing that made me undo my coat because my chest had suddenly become too crowded: a road made of tiles, running along the river, children hopscotching with their lungs clear, their mothers chatting in a language of relief I have been trying to learn my whole life. “It’s not to scale,” he said, as if he had disappointed me, and I told him to leave the scale to the fish.

And then the river decided to give me a gift I did not know how to receive and could not refuse. Gideon called at dawn when the light had just started to remember that there is a distinction between sky and water worth noting. His voice had a rasp in it I had not heard since the winter the car went under and never came up where it was supposed to. “We found one,” he said, and he did not apologize for making me the kind of woman who is summoned by that sentence. “Not him,” he added, and the relief went through me like a flood that doesn’t sweep things so much as rearrange them kindly. “But close enough. You’ll want to see the way the streak sits on the windshield. You’ll want to hear the trap loosen when we bring it up. You’ll want to tell me if the river is being generous or cruel.”

The Retort ticked as if it were listening. The coat waited on its hook like a dog who knows it will not be taken for a walk and graciously doesn’t hold a grudge. I put on my boots. I put the marble in my pocket. I wrote a note for Etta and shoved it under her door where it would catch on the mat. I told Aunt Sable nothing, because she would know and be furious, and then forgive me in a tone that would pour molasses into my ears and make me feel twelve. I went where I always go when something old is about to come up: to the bank behind the old factory where the ground remembers permission to be unstable.

Gideon stood with his back to the truck crane that was doing its very best to pretend it knew this river and its temper. The men he had borrowed for the pull had that bowed head you only see at gravesides and in kitchens when babies are newly discovered. The cable slithered down into the brown and then tautened like a hymn. When the car came up it was so ordinary I had to close my eyes and make it something else to be able to bear looking at it. It was a mid-aughts sedan the color of bad rain. The algae had made lace along the dash. The glass had gone green in the way glass goes green when it has been promised a home underwater and then betrayed. The windshield streak he had spoken about was there—a smear like something written and wiped away in a hurry.

On the hood someone had scratched the triangle years ago and had done a bad job. The base was intact. The point was blunted. The line through it had been hesitant. It had not been the symbol from the pallets. It had been an attempt by a person who had spent a lot of time waiting in this car and was trying to make their boredom into a geometry. In the passenger footwell, wrapped in a half-disintegrated grocery bag like an aunt who refused to go to church with bare arms, there was a tin with my mother’s initials on it. You never recover from your mother’s handwriting; it continues to instruct you about the shape of letters long after she stops correcting you at the table.

Gideon let me retrieve it. That is what love looks like in my town sometimes; men let women pull things out of the river that might break them, because the women will do it anyway and this way the men get to stand near enough to catch their elbows if they sway. The tin was light in the way of tins, which is to say it felt like an insult until you remembered it holds weight that is not measured in ounces. I opened it on the bank with my thighs bracing my elbows so I wouldn’t scatter whatever was inside into the water like the ending to a tasteful movie. There was a photograph of me and my father on the day the dock we didn’t own seemed to belong to us because we were so loud. There was a scrap of a map with a circle around the bend where we were standing, as if by circling a place you could persuade it not to misbehave. There was a piece of chalk. There was a key with no tag. There was a note. I recognized the stroke of my mother’s angry cursive from the loop in the J.

June, it said, as if she had known where the tin would go and who would one day fish it up with hands that knew more than her twelve-year-old’s had. If you are reading this, I am not mad at you for going to the river. Nobody will tell you this but the river listens when you aren’t talking. Your father loved it wrong and he loved it right and both things can be true. Do not let them convince you that fire and water are enemies. People say that when they mean they don’t want to have to learn to hold more than one kind of danger. Use the key for something besides leaving. Your Aunt Sable will pretend she knew about this tin and she did not, because I did not tell her, because sometimes you have to keep a secret to keep a person. I am sorry. I am not sorry.

There was no postscript. I put the tin back together in the order it had greeted me because I am a superstitious woman when it comes to sequences, and then I put it under my coat as if it needed warming. Gideon watched my face with the professional pity of a man who has lost enough to make him good at it and not so much that he has made a performance of his capacity. “Generous,” he said, and I nodded because he was right. It is generous to give a thing back even if it is not the exact one you begged to see. It is generous to send up a reminder that symbols are sloppy and people are sloppier and you can spend your life scolding them for it or you can make an oven and teach the town how to feed it.

On the way home the road hummed under my tires like it had something to add and was waiting to be asked nicely. I took the long way by the Nestlé grounds and chalked a sentence on the wall where the cutlery words had once been. The cutlery was gone; someone had come and collected it, perhaps with dreams of art or signs. The sentence had to be rewritten three times because when I tried to make it pretty the chalk broke, and when I made it ordinary it held. We will not throw the hard parts away, I wrote finally, because you can’t. We will embed them. We will stand on them. We will learn to like the sound our feet make when they meet the proof.

That night I did a strange thing and I do not know whether it was wise. I took the key from the tin and I pressed it into the tile I had made the second night with the vein like a wrist. The tile took the impression like a good pupil and the key came away with a tiny kiss, green dust on its teeth. I put it on a cord and I put the cord around my neck because sometimes you have to leave a thing where your pulse can argue with it. She watched me do it and did not laugh. “You going to wear that when you go see the man who thinks burning wrong is a personality?” she asked, and I told her, “Yes, and I’m going to hand him a tile and dare him to stand on it.”

“Make him stand on it in front of his friends,” she said, pragmatic as kindling, and this, too, is love of a sort.

I slept and woke and slept again because some days that is the work. I did not dream about cars or bales or gulls, which felt like a mercy. I dreamed about floors. Not pretty floors. Floors that have seen winter boots and babies and the corners of couches being dragged by women who don’t have help. Floors embedded with green squares that hold the breath of the city so its children do not have to. I dreamed about the boy’s fox skittering down Oneida with ten tails and a beating tile and people stepping back to make room without looking up from their bags. I dreamed about Eloise’s hair at rest. I dreamed about a mirror that did not need to show me both to make me believe we could be two and one without smudging. In the morning the marble felt light in my pocket, the way things feel when they have taken their own advice and rested. I brewed tea that tasted like the season had remembered cinnamon by accident. I opened the shop. I stitched a hem for a girl getting married at the church that wants to pretend it dislikes me. I soldered a lamp that had belonged to a grandfather who did like me. I labeled a jar evidence of a boundary you kept. I waited for the next thing to need both of us, and when it came—because it always comes—I put on the coat without apology and I did not look away when the heat smiled.

Chapter Eight

The day after the tin, the town discovered a talent for walking around the word incinerator like it was a sleeping dog. Flyers sprouted on telephone poles with words like thermal recovery and energy from waste and artist's rendering in which a building with no right angles glowed benevolently while a family of four held hands and did not cough. A man in a jacket so close to navy it made him vanish if he stood too near the police chief introduced himself to Eloise in the hallway outside the council chamber and said things like public-private partnership and pilot facility and then said my name like we had been introduced in a room I had accidentally missed. He had a smile that could pick a lock and an eye for a camera that didn’t need a lens. His card said Morrison & Kent, Regional Development. The card was heavy in a way that asked to be kept as a coaster.

Eloise slid the card across my counter with two fingers like she was returning a knife to a drawer. “He’s got a stack of policy white papers taller than his ego,” she said, which on a different day might have been funny. “He says he likes the tiles. He says there’s a way to scale them that involves concrete and fencing and a smokestack we can rename a flute if we want to.”

“I do want to rename things,” I said, and flipped the card like a coin and let it land face down because I am childish when it comes to fate. “I don’t want a flute that only plays one note and calls it a symphony.”

“He wants to meet,” she said, glancing at the door as if the bell might tell on her. “He wants to shake your hand. He wants to learn the word Retort and file it under local color.”

“I’ll bring the coat,” I said. “If he puts a match on my counter I’m going to make him stand on a tile until he decides whether ash is something he respects.”

Aunt Sable sat me down with coffee that had been on the burner long enough to develop opinions and told me the one story I had never let her tell properly. It came slowed by age and sped by impatience. My mother loved a dock more than a pew because a dock never pretended it could hold what it couldn’t. She loved my father because he wore the same face whether he was watching a storm or a stove. She hated the car because it made leaving too easy. She kept the tin because it made staying a task, not a default. The night the river took the car, it took everything that had been kept between them like towels. It returned rotten fish and a hubcap and a story that the town folded into itself the way a person folds a letter before they throw it out and then retrieves it, smooths it, and decides to keep it a little longer. “Your mother could have become a ruin,” Sable said, watching the steam from her cup as if it might deliver a verdict. “She chose not to. She chose work. She chose, sometimes, to burn small things before they could become bonfires. She messed that up as often as she succeeded, because we are messy people. She did not tell me about the tin because she knew I would hide at least one of the pieces someplace I would later forget.”

I wanted to be angry with my mother for trusting a river with her note when I was twelve and so hungry for stories that weren’t about loss, and I wanted not to be because the note had reached my hands like it had walked there. I wanted to be angry with Sable for not telling me sooner about the nights she had sat up with my mother counting the seconds between thunder and lightning and deciding when to move furniture away from windows. I wanted not to be, because she had chosen to be the kind of woman I could call when my other self said three nights. It is exhausting to want the fair versions of people and to keep choosing the real ones anyway.

Morrison from Morrison & Kent had the decency to call me June and the indecency to take in my shop like it was a stage set. He saw the jars and the coat with his eyes and the Retort with his pupils. He spoke in paragraphs that have killed more towns than storms, verbs that make nouns do labor they didn’t sign up for. “We see an opportunity to integrate community-based solutions,” he said, which translated to: your mess is an aesthetic we can monetize. “We see an opportunity to localize control within a regional footprint,” which meant: we will put a fence around your air and sell it back to you with a bow. He admired the tile the way you admire something a child has made before you usher it to the refrigerator, smile, and go back to the real conversation. He touched the green and didn’t notice the way it thrummed because he doesn’t live with his hands.

“You’ll call it a kiln so we think pottery,” I said. “You’ll call it cogeneration so we think winter sweaters and not smoke.” I poured tea because I am the kind of witch who believes hospitality is a spell strong enough to make men talk true. “You’ll call me innovative so I think I’m important and then you’ll file me under color and call my name if there’s a ribbon to cut.”

“We prefer the term energy hub,” he said cheerfully. “Imagine the message. No more fires in alleys. No more confusion. We collect, we process, we capture. You keep your tiles. We keep your city’s air clean. The grant money likes us. The state likes numbers.”

“The river doesn’t like fences,” I said, because there is always a point at which you have to line up your allegiances out loud. “And neither do I. Capturing breath is not the same as denying it. I will not build you a pretty chimney.”

He did what men like him do when faced with women like me: he smiled like our dance had been charming and announced he would see me at the town hall meeting. He left a brochure that smelled like ink and confidence and I used it to level a stool that has always leaned just enough to make you feel alert.

Delia Mott took the brochure and wrote Not a flute, a pipe snake on the cover in pencil so light you had to squint. She stood in my doorway, which had become a threshold for women bringing me unsentimental truth, and told me she had colleagues who liked Morrison’s hair and colleagues who liked my jars and some who liked both and none who liked the river when it got opinionated. “You’ll need numbers that don’t blush,” she said. “You’ll need a demonstration that doesn’t smell like babies will later cough. They’re going to bring a stack of tires to the meeting and call it hypothetically, and you’re going to keep your face from changing when someone says dioxin and looks at you like they’re asking whether you’d like a second cookie.”

“I can hold a straight face,” I said. “I have made hems on prom dresses so poorly conceived they were in violation of a building code and I did not lecture once.”

She almost smiled. “I’ll bring a meter. You bring your patience. We’ll let the town decide which smoke it likes living with.”

The boy from Thirteenth sat cross-legged on my floor with the fox and told me he had a name he wasn’t born with and would like me to use. “Rook,” he said, and making the k made his mouth pleased. “Like the bird and like the game, but mostly like the bird. The bird likes trash. The bird knows how to look at it different.”

“Rook,” I repeated, and let it settle in my mouth as if it were a seed that had chosen me. He laced wire into the fox’s shoulder while he talked about a woman with bracelets who had asked for a dolphin again and he had said, “No ma’am, I don’t do mammals,” and then felt bad and offered her a fish that looked like a knife. I gave him a cuff I had lined with gold and he put it on like a royal and then pretended not to feel taller.

We set the date for the town hall and I spent the morning making sure the Retort did not have a grudge about being asked to perform. The coat hung on its hook like a person listening for their name under noise. I cut more tiles than I needed and not enough for what I wanted. I wrote a list in the way my mother taught me to write lists—verbs first, then nouns, then people—and tried not to read it as a spell. I wrote: bring jars, bring Delia, bring patience, bring stitching for when men say machines and mean women, bring tea. I did not write bring the other me because she is not a thing I set out anymore; she is a weather that arrives when addressed and when ignored both. I put the tin with the key in the drawer under the register where I keep the money and the candy I pretend I don’t like. I told it to behave. It didn’t answer, which is how you know you’re dealing with an heirloom and not a demon.

The town hall was held in the old gym because it is the only room that can hold our collective self-importance. The bleachers creaked under people who do not believe in bleachers. Eloise had her pen out like a wand and her hair tacked back like a decision. Pastor Lennox had ceded the front row to Etta, who had brought a string bag with two oranges in it and two small stones that I knew were intended to be thrown only if someone said witch in a way that made it unignorable. Morrison & Kent had set up a banner with a logo that was attempting to be a wave and a lightning bolt and instead looked like a checkmark stretched wrong. Rook stood by the door with the fox, because we had agreed it should come to meetings like a dog you trust not to bite even if someone deserves it.

We had rehearsed without saying we had rehearsed. Nate had loaned us the small roll-off and the ugly duct. Delia had brought a meter that made grown men look like they were considering a proposal. I had stacked the tiles within reach like arguments I would only use if provoked. The firefighters hung at the back in posture that said we will not be recruited and then, under it, a posture that said we might, because we prefer work to talk.

Morrison spoke in the generous lower register men save for good wine and civic pride. He had slides full of arrows, and arrows are always lying. He had numbers that made smoke look like the kind of cloud you nap on. He said partnership to mean control and resilience to mean purchase order. He said Ms. Weaver twice in a tone that had respect wrapped around condescension like pastry around a cheap sausage. He gestured at the Retort like he had introduced us to each other and we had been grateful.

I did not interrupt him because the only thing worse than a man with good hair is a woman who lets him have an easy villain. When it was my turn, I did not look at the cameras. I looked where Gideon had planted himself, one hand on the railing because he does not like burning in rooms. I spoke the way you speak to a river when you are unsure whether it is asleep or only pretending. I said we built this with hands you know. I said we are already capturing what you cannot make not burn. I said you can come to the lean-to and put your own breath on the glass and watch it fog and clear. I said my name. I did not say witch. I did not say no to the plant. I said we will not be eaten by our solution.

We lit the Retort. The ducting hummed forward like a horse that had learned the command in another language but trusted the hand. The jars fogged and cleared in that steady measure that has become my favorite rhythm. The heat went where it was supposed to because we had laid the story ahead of it like a track. Delia watched the meter the way musicians watch a conductor they don’t fully like but have agreed to obey. She held up a finger when someone in a hat shouted about toxins, then displayed a line on a screen that refused to move into panic. Morrison smiled in a way that said, charming, but asked for comparison. His men brought a barrel and a stack of what they called farm film: plastic that has seen hay and sun and a litany of hungers. They asked if we would mind. Eloise said go ahead, and her voice had a wire in it.

They lit the barrel the wrong way on purpose, and if you think that sentence isn’t a spell then you haven’t lived in a town where men create their own villains for sport. The fire took gleeful umbrage. It produced the particular cough of heat that is half chemical, half affront. Delia’s meter began to show its numbers. People leaned back into their coats and into their opinions. I felt the coat on the hook unlatch itself, which is a trick I don’t recommend allowing unless you know for a fact you can carry both yourself and your other without dropping your tea.

She stepped into me without theatrics because the gym doesn’t like them unless there’s a band. We put our hand—the one with the mark—on the duct and the Retort took the yowl from the barrel the way a grandmother takes a toddler who has decided a tantrum is the only way to tell the truth. The jars experimented with blowing their tops and then remembered themselves. The fire made a last bid for romance and writhed. I watched the room feel the difference between spectacle and function. If you are lucky in your life, you get to perform that reveal twice: once for a town, once for yourself. I breathed in for the sake of the meter and out for the sake of my lungs.

Morrison did not get hotter, which is the problem with men like him. He stayed even and smiled like he had made this happen. He asked about scale and costs and the inevitability of waste and whether I had considered licensing. He offered to help with permitting for a larger hood and a friendlier word for capture. He suggested a ribbon-cutting in spring. He said he would send over a team to evaluate. Only once did he slip and say incineration, and then he corrected to thermal reclamation with the grace of a dancer who never lets you see the turn.

After, in the shuffle that follows demonstrations and before the fights reassert themselves, a man with the kind of face you find on high school photographs in cases in hallways asked me for a tile for his mother. He whispered that she can’t breathe in summer and he can carry a square better than a machine, and I handed him one with my mother’s name under my breath because sometimes prayers are logistics. The firefighters came and asked for cuffs and did not bother to pretend they were being charitable. Pastor Lennox put his hand on the Retort like a man laying hands on a congregant who has confessed something heavy and wants the weight redistributed, not removed. Eloise spoke quietly to Delia in a language of numbers and favors. Rook slipped the fox through the legs of men who did not look down and smiled when no one tripped.

I saw him, then. The he from the woman with the sunburn and the errands and the confession she had practically stapled to my counter. He had a mustache that belonged to a different mouth and a jacket poor men buy when they decide to look rich once and never again. He stayed at the edges of the crowd where people who collect allies stand. He laughed when Morrison talked about jobs and nodded when the barrel complained and looked bored when we made the Retort hum. He caught my eye and didn’t drop it. He was not the man who cut the fence; he was the man who tells that man when to arrive and with what tools. In a country song he’d be the one who drives the truck to the line and leaves it idling.

He left before I could decide if I was going to tell him my name and ask for his, and I let him. Chasing men like that is a way to forget why you built anything. Aunt Sable says you can lose a decade in one pair of eyes that make you feel like you are a version of yourself that would be fun at dinner.

That night, after the gym had been returned to a room for sweating without stakes and the Retort was asleep enough to count as resting and the tile stack was three squares taller than exhaustion, she and I stood in the kitchen with the mirror face-up like a thinned lake. The coat hung a little lower because wet air makes even magic heavier. I did what I had been practicing doing without rehearsing: I held both our gazes at once and did not flinch at the overlay. “I want a braid,” I said, which on paper looks romantic and in practice sounds like two women deciding about bone.

“You want to make a schedule,” she said, because our humor sits on the same stubborn shelf. “You want Tuesdays you and Thursdays me. You want me to punch a clock. You want to be able to blame me when you say yes to more fire than you can digest.”

“I want to not wake up with sugar on my teeth and the triangle on my brick,” I said. “I want to be able to say to my aunt that I am done outsourcing my scorch. I want to stand in the alley with the coat on and feel you decide to stay in my hand.”

“Then stop pretending I am only your badness,” she said, and there it was; the particular nasty of truth that loves me enough to tell me I am a coward. “You call me when you want speed and you call me when you want courage and you call me when a man says he knows better what to do with heat and you want to look frightening while you defy him. It would be sweet if it weren’t lazy.”

“I will learn to look frightening with a needle,” I said, and laughed at myself because I already do.

We braided without string. We braided with breath. We braided with the sound of the Retort cooling and the distant plop of something large in the river deciding to surface then changing its mind because even fish are ambivalent sometimes. I took a strand of hair and burned it in the flame of a candle we had made with leftover paraffin and beeswax I bought from a man on a back road who carves saints out of stumps and never learned to charge appropriately. She took a bit of ash and traced a line on my wrist. I took the key from my neck and pressed it to the mirror until it fogged and cleared, and she held the mirror steady in case I shook. When we were done, we looked like the same woman to anybody who would photograph us for the newspaper. Inside, a door clicked. A small one. The kind people use when they pretend they are not leaving or entering. We stood there for a whole minute and breathed. I do not know yet whether it will hold forever or until spring. That is honest. That is the best I can give you when you ask for permanence in a town where almost everything floats.

Two days later, because I had made a braid and the world wanted to tug it to see if it would hold, the plastic cult—which really is only three people and a Facebook page and a penchant for drawing triangles on picnic tables while waiting for their fries—announced a parade. They called it Crackle Walk and designed a logo with a match sticking up like a flag from a trash can. They said they would bring their bags and their beliefs and their lighters and their right to air, and they met in the parking lot of the shuttered video store where nostalgia knows how to make itself look like policy. I put on the coat and did not bring the Retort because there is no arguing with spectacle except by not feeding it.

Rook came because he had made signs for the teenagers who wanted to walk but not admit they were walking for anything other than an excuse not to do homework. Etta came because she does not know how to stay home when a town is making a choice in public. Pastor Lennox came because he insists on testifying with his face even when his voice isn’t asked for. Gideon came because he had a suspicion that someone would attempt to make a fire on or near a vehicle. Delia did not come because she would be accused of taking a side and she is not embarrassed to tell me she sometimes sits in her truck and eats a sandwich while the town burns or learns. Eloise came because she comes to everything she can possibly come to, and when she cannot, she sends a woman who is shorter and angrier.

They had a barrel. Of course they had a barrel. They had three. They had triangles painted in a stencil style that I now recognized like the handwriting of a boy who has copied a phrase until he has convinced himself he invented it. They had slogans that would be more fun if they didn’t sound like boys putting their hands in the air at the back of class because making noise is a way to make sure you don’t have to listen. They had a man in the jacket who will never be rich, calling phrases like freedom and choice and witch but on our side now, which is the irony I’m not sure the universe will ever get tired of.

I walked up and held a tile like a communion and the way the teenagers looked at me made the inside of my elbow hurt. “Pick one,” I said. “Stand on it. Light your barrel. See if you like the way the air feels when your toes are telling the truth.” Two of them did it because two is the correct number for this town. The third boy made a loud speech about lies and marbles and the river probably being a gimmick and then his lighter failed because sometimes God is a cheap Bic. The tile under their feet hummed and they looked down like they had just learned that floor is a verb.

One of the triangle-men—the ones with mustaches they grew as if the seventies had been a country they were patriotic for—stepped up to me with a match he’d been rolling between his fingers in a way that indicated both habit and desire for attention. He held it so close to my coat that I smelled the sulfur in the moment before the flare and my braid tightened like a girl flexing her hands. The coat took the heat and held it and cooled it and I did not move, again not out of bravery, out of stubbornness. I pressed the tile into his chest, and he took it because it was either that or admit he didn’t know what to do with his hands. “Stand on that,” I said, and he did, because even men who dislike witchcraft like instructions when everyone is watching.

The barrels burned small because we didn’t give them oxygen to be dramatic. The tiles brightened. The breath fogged the not-jar of the air and then, because physics agrees to be reasonable in public sometimes, lifted. The men with the triangles ran out of slogans and stood with their hands out, waiting to be told what to do next. Eloise told them to pick up their cigarette butts. Etta told them to take off their hats if they were coming into the co-op for chili. Pastor Lennox told them nothing because he had decided to take my hint about the silence that works as well as any sermon. Rook ran the fox through the barrel smoke and laughed when it didn’t cough.

That night the river did its trick with the moon. It doesn’t reverse unless the wind force-feeds it the lake, but it can look like it has decided to. It wore a skin that made me want to step into it for the sheer meanness of its calm. I took the key out of the tin and went to the Nestlé wall and considered the locks this town has that are worth opening and the ones that need to stay stuck because getting through them would only let out things that can’t be taught manners. I chalked a small box on the brick and made a mark and another, then pressed the key into the mortar like you teach a word to a child by putting it on their tongue. The brick accepted and then rejected me politely, the way some women do when you are trying to get them to let you escort them and they have never needed the arm you are offering. I laughed because there is a kind of prayer that looks exactly like a witch giggling alone in an alley.

Gideon found me there and did not pretend he had been out to buy milk. He had the look he gets when he sees the river carrying a promise only he will notice because the rest of us are busy with land. “You ever going to put a tile on the boat?” he asked, casual in the way of men who are not casual about anything. “Might be I don’t want to be the only thing that breathes right on it.”

“I’ll put one under the pump,” I said. “I’ll put one where your foot goes when you pull a thing from the water and you don’t want your right knee to tell you cruel stories for three days after.”

He nodded as if that had been the right answer and then, like a man admitting something to a woman he sees too clearly to manipulate, said, “I sat on my porch last night and I thought about your father. I thought about the way he laughed in the bar like someone had told him a joke so close to true it made him generous. I thought about the miles of water between where that car first decided to be a fish and where we found it. I thought about how heavy things become not because of their metal but because of the place they live. I thought about your mother’s handwriting. I thought, if I had a daughter, would I let her read it. I don’t know what the good answer is.”

“The good answer is that you don’t get to decide what she reads,” I said, and laughed into my scarf so the words came back warm. “You get to decide whether you hand it to her or the river does. The river is worse at timing. Sometimes she is perfect in spite of herself.”

We walked back up Oneida with tiles tucked under our coats like contraband and the sky doing that winter thing where it pretends it will snow if we all wish hard enough. I put one tile on the library steps before I unlocked my door because I want the air in there to be kind to the children who think the stacks are a forest and the roof is the sky. I put one in the foyer of my building where Mrs. Calabrese has started peeking and pretending she approves. I put one under the table where I work so the breath I chain to glass has a reason to stay. I wrote a word on the mirror I had never let myself write because it felt like a confession that might dissolve under heat. Home, I wrote, and waited for it to fog and clear, and it did both.

When Morrison called the next morning, he did not apologize. He did not congratulate. He asked if he could send his team to measure and photograph and advise. I told him to bring coffee and gloves and to come ready to sand duct edges so nobody lost a knuckle. He did not laugh. He said a time. I said the door would be unlocked. Then I called Delia and told her to park across the street with her meter and a face so unamused the sun would move over one block rather than shine right on us. I called Eloise and told her to bring the kind of pen that bleeds through paper because we would need to sign things that don’t let us out easy. I told Rook to stay home because I did not want to explain to corporate men why the fox had better posture than their boss. I told Aunt Sable nothing because it is good to give an old woman a morning where she is not required to remind a younger one to not catch fire unnecessarily.

They came with hard hats and shoes none of us would wear to do work you plan to sweat in. They came with their own words for duct and flange and heat and none of those words included blessing and patience. I made them tea with honey from the man on the back road and let them sit on my stools, which are the kind of stools that make you tell the truth because they wobble if you lie. They measured my mouth. They clicked their tongues at my jars. They took photographs of the coat as if it were an antique that had wandered down from a museum storeroom and gotten ideas. One of them, a woman with earrings shaped like letters, asked me how I stitched the lining and I told her with a story and a little bit of science. She did not roll her eyes. A man named Nick braced a sheet of steel while Nate drilled and the bit screamed and nobody yelled witch even once. It was progress in a way that felt like a tile curing, slow, then quick, then sudden and obvious.

After their visit, Morrison stood at my door with his hands in his coat like a boy who hasn’t learned where to put them when he wants to ask to be let in. He said all the things polite people say when they have failed to win a round and are trying not to show their discomfort with not being beloved.
