He started to ask me something and then swallowed it, which is either manners or strategy and I am not always good at telling the difference. He settled on, “Do you ever wish you were just a tailor,” and I told him, “I wish a lot of things,” and then I told him a thing my mother wrote in a note I did not invite him to see: that fire and water are not enemies, that people use enemies when they are lazy. He nodded like he understood and then went away like he did not.

That night, because the world enjoys testing knots when your hands are chapped and you only want to go to bed, the wind decided to come down Oneida with its shoulders. The bags on porches sang their ugly little songs. The bins clattered and grew hungry. Somewhere, a boy with a lighter and an empty had an idea. Somewhere else, a woman looked up at the ceiling and wondered if it was worth moving the couch. I locked my door, then unlocked it, then put my hand on the Retort like a person telling their dog it is time to go out. She was already standing. The coat slid from the hook and didn’t bother to pretend it needed me. We went to the alley. We breathed. We waited. We made our mouths agreeable to the kind of smoke this town refuses to admit it likes, and then we turned that liking into tile, into floor, into a sentence we will stand on until our knees give out and we are replaced by a woman who knows how to thread a needle and convince heat that the better story is the one where it behaves.

Chapter Ten hid its face behind a sheet-metal sky and let the town find its breath in the seam between freeze and thaw that makes buildings cough. The river went flat as a lie told too often and then rucked up without warning, and I understood we were in that part of winter where decisions get made by people who think weather is a conversation partner. I woke with my mouth tasting like solder and tea, not sugar, which meant the braid was holding. She hovered at the edge of my hand the way cats hover at the edge of affection, and when I reached for a pin my fingers knew which self was better at picking a sliver from cloth and which was better at holding steady while heat argued. The tiles under the counter kept their hum like a choir with sense, not ambition. Outside, the street wore a crust of salt and disappointment and the little birds did their frantic hop-growl-hop dance in the gutter like what they wanted was entirely reasonable and the world just needed to get out of their way.

Eloise stopped by first, not because she likes mornings but because she had been up all night reading a stack of documents taller than the fern she has kept alive in her office by threatening it. She had Morrison’s card bent into a tool for opening stubborn jars and a look that told me her hair had won. “They want an MOU,” she said without ceremony, as though I were a person who keeps my initials in a drawer ready to be affixed to something ornamental and then regretted. “They want to call it a pilot, but it smells like permanence with addenda. They want language about compliance and they want us to say thank you.”

“I can say thank you without meaning it,” I offered, pouring coffee into a cup that had been chipped back when my mother thought she was going to move to a city where women wear lipstick to the post office. “I cannot say incinerator with a smile. I can say Retort so many times it becomes a lullaby.”

“We don’t have to accept their money,” she said with the lighter kind of despair that comes when you are lying to yourself for strategic reasons. “We could do it with grants and a bake sale and my retirement. Don’t make a face. I’m only half joking. I don’t want to sell our breath to a man who calls smoke an opportunity.”

“Put the tile on your desk,” I said, because sometimes you give your friends work that looks like superstition and they will do it if they love you enough. “Stand on it when you read. It will keep you honest with yourself about which part of your mouth is speaking.”

She stood. She did as I asked. She closed her eyes, which in Eloise is a prayer. When she opened them again she had that pinched look like a woman who has decided to carry something heavy to the top of a hill out of spite. “There’s a hearing in Albany,” she said. “Delia wants you. Morrison wants you. Your aunt wants you to stay home and boil bones for broth because she knows travel eats you. I want you to come and be useful and to also be small. I hate that those are the choices.”

“I know how to be small,” I said. “I learned it early. I prefer loud when loud is a tool, but I can be folded and put in a bag like a sweater if it gets us past the door.”

After she left I made a floor where there had been one, only now it had an opinion. I set three tiles in the threshold and grouted them with slurry and patience. They looked like a lake you could bring inside without getting the rugs in trouble. I made a sign on a piece of slate that used to be a menu in a café that sold feeling instead of food: Step however you like, it said. Notice the difference. People came in and did. Old men from the barbershop hopped like children then pretended they hadn’t. A girl with a backpack set too heavy for her bones stepped on the green and got weepy in the way you do when you’ve been holding your breath for longer than a minute and someone says you don’t have to. Rook came in with the fox and made it bow to the square politely, which set the tone.

Rook’s fox had become a kind of maypole without the ringing and the fights. Children tied ribbons around the tails and some of the knots were so bad they held, because that is true of children and true of towns. He had given the creature small iron feet scavenged from a chair and the tile-heart sat just behind a piece of clear plastic that used to be the lid for a cake nobody enjoyed and everyone ate anyway. The fox did not look alive, but it looked like it had no patience for lying about its condition, and I loved it for that. Rook had started a club without saying club, and a handful of kids with cold hands and eyes too alert for their age came by after school with bags full of plastics cleaned with effort. He told them their hands mattered more than their finds and they believed him because he said it as if he expected them to argue and win.

Pastor Lennox came in with his tie pin misaligned and no pamphlets, which told me he had fought and perhaps lost in a room that smelled like coffee and winter boots. He put his hands on the counter the way a man puts his hands on a piano he was punished for loving when he was twelve. “The board,” he said, by which he meant the five people in his church who wear responsibility like perfume, “are divided. They want the regional plant because the brochure has a picture of a sunset on it. They want your tiles because their grandchildren sleep better after a day with one underfoot. They want me to tell them what stewardship is, and I want to tell them it is sorting shame into the right bag and putting love in the clear bin and taking the rest to the river once a month and asking the water to tell you when you are lying.”

“You can tell them we capture breath,” I said, because some phrases can be loaned without losing their magic. “You can tell them I will tile your aisle if they let me, and we will see if the pews complain. You can tell them the plant wants a fence. I want a floor.”

He smiled without heat and it meant more than a fervent grin would have. “If I say floor from the pulpit, Lennox & Sons will accuse me of witchcraft by way of interior design,” he said. “I will say ground. I will say footing. I will say we do not know how to behave with our feet. I will ask them to practice.”

He left me a small bag of cash from a funeral luncheon because grief tips well and sometimes has nowhere else to put its hands. He promised me nothing and that is why I trusted him.

The he who had taught a woman to ruin her kettle the fast way sent me a message through a boy whose ears I would like to protect from a decade when men confide laziness to the nearest youth with good posture. It was a note on paper torn from a legal pad, carefully folded, the kind a man’s hand does when it wants to pretend to be a gentleman. The meeting place was the old tannery; the hour was the kind that breaks a neck. Aunt Sable told me not to go in the tone she saves for when she knows I will and would like the points on her warning recorded. I wore the coat and no perfume. I told Eloise by text and she wrote back three skulls and a thumbs-up and a time she would start calling people with keys if I did not answer my phone. Gideon watched me walk by and did not stop me because he believes in me in a way that is not flattering and is entirely useful.

The tannery still exhaled ghosts of hides and labor when it got warm enough indoors for old air to remember its vows. This was not one of those nights. The frost on the windows looked like breath that had curled around a lead paint warning and decided to make art of it. He was there with two others, men with hands softer than their talk. They had jackets that had learned the smell of garages and slogans that had not learned to be ashamed of themselves yet. They did not say the word cult because men in this town only use that word for women, never for the rooms where they bring fire and a sense of grievance like it is a hand tool.

“We don’t want to burn the whole town,” he said, which is the kind of sentence that makes you check for an exit even if you have magic. “We want to use what’s there. We want to be in charge of the heat. We want to show the city it can’t police everything with guilt. You have a mouth,” he added, glancing at my coat in a way that made me check which part of me was the dangerous one. “We have hands. We could make something bigger than jars and tiles. We could make something tragic to be righteous about.”

I have learned how to be courteous when I am furious because women who live in small towns need to be good at survival on a dozen registers. “You want fires with witnesses,” I said. “You want a river that will take credit for your mess. You want me at the front of your parade so when the police take pictures you can say we’re in it together and you are an ally to a woman who burns.”

He smiled like he had been told it looked good on him once and had never stopped. “You set it up and we’ll make sure you have protection.”

“Protection,” I repeated, as if I had never met the word and wanted to know its preferred pronouns. “From who?”

“From us,” he said, and that made me laugh in a way I am not proud of. There are laughs that keep you alive and they are cruel laughs, and you try not to grow fond of them because they turn on you when you are tired.

I did not bring Delia or Nate to the tannery; I brought them to the night after. I left the tannery with my hands by my sides and my back itching in the way backs itch when men you would not invite to dinner stare and try to make you into an epiphany. In my pocket the key from my mother’s tin pressed a bruise into my thigh so deep I could have chalked it and called it a map. The next day Delia and I stood in the street and watched the traffic like two sisters who had decided to go for a walk in front of a battlefield. “They’ll try the Retort,” Delia said, adjusting her meter like a woman adjusting a necklace given by an ex she still wears because it looks better on her than on any apology. “Sabotage is exciting. They are bored.”

“Do we use law?” I asked, because sometimes I like to fantasize about a system that will look down and notice our breath without us having to paint it green.

“We use rope and we use neighbors and we use a camera and we use boredom against them,” she said. “We let them be as dull as they are in public and then we do not give them the spice of outrage. Believe me, I hate it. I prefer lawsuits. But lawsuits are winter. They take and take and you only see the green in the spring.”

They came late, thinking the darkness could be their mother. Nate and Gideon were visible and useful; I was not. I sat in the sewing chair inside with the mirror flat and the coat swung over the back like a woman tired of standing. She did not need to come but she did, because we have agreed that sometimes the theater is necessary. The men tried the door and found it latched with a thing Morrison’s men would call a device and Nate calls a good decision. One climbed, as if he thought vertigo had a crush on him. He met mine instead; the window had a tile in it and the tile sang when his glove hit the frame, and he found his grip disagreeing with him because devotion to art will get in your bones if you hold it often enough. They gave up on subtlety and went for the can, and the can failed because Gideon had replaced it with water because he enjoys a joke when it is useful. They ran. We did not. Delia took photographs with a camera that is also a witness because it records numbers in the language a court likes. Nate said a sentence in a dialect made entirely of swear words and conjugations of to fix and then went home and kissed his wife and did not tell her anything.

Everyone pretended not to know what had happened. That is mercy and also a bad habit. Eloise took the photographs and slid them into a folder that will only be opened if we need leverage, and leverage is one of those words I have learned to use without grimacing. The men with the stencils learned where the camera was on the light pole by my alley and drew their triangles a block away. The cracks of their symbol went shallow and the chalk wore quicker because somewhere a boy with a sleeve that can take scrubbing had decided his corner should be clean. I do not count these as victories. I count them as pauses in the kind of weather that tires you.

The blizzard came a week later, a real one, not a tantrum. It arrived overnight with the confidence of a guest who knows the spare key is under the frog on the porch. The lake gave the town its shoulder and the town bent like a woman who has learned how to carry without asking for help. The power had the decency to wait until morning to fail, and then it failed with the seriousness we expect of it. Etta’s kitchen went dark and she finished the soup on a camping stove that had boiled water for arguments and reconciliations in its time. The co-op went dim and people breathed on the glass where the good bread hides and pretended that fog was a plan. The church opened its doors because that is what churches like his do even when the board wants to say something about liability. The transfer station closed and sighed in relief because the bales hate damp.

I opened my door and the Retort breathed like a dragon who has agreed to be of service. The coat warmed the air in a way that made my teeth feel like they are a part of my face and not an argument. We did not burn plastic to heat people because I would like to keep being invited to parties. We burned pallets cut down to apology and scrap from a woodshop where a woman knows how to plane without swearing. We captured what needed capturing and let heat do what heat does when it is loved correctly. People came and stood on the tiles and stood near the duct and crushed their hands in their pockets and told each other stories about winters that made this one look like a kind child and then ate Etta’s soup because kindness is a sedative.

Pastor Lennox brought blankets from the church that smelled like the cedar chest they think is a chapel. Eloise sat on a stool and fell asleep in a posture she would have fired someone for having in a meeting. Gideon stationed himself near the door like a bouncer for weather. Rook set the fox under the coat’s hem in a way that made it look like an altar boy being trained to be useful and not get caught up in his own metaphor. Aunt Sable came in late with a casserole that contains at least three recipes and opinion, and she touched my face as if confirming a rumor of fever. “You keep your scalp covered when you go out,” she said, which was not a request and therefore got obeyed. “You let other people put wood on your altar and do not fuss about how they stack it. This is the kind of night where pride pretends to be a coat and fails to keep you warm.”

In the middle of the afternoon a boy pounded on the door with urgency that made the coat tighten. He had the particular white of a face that has met cold past polite and has the will to demand warmth from a half-sleeping town. Gideon was out the door before he finished his sentence, which was two words: he fell. The river did not look like a sentence you could read that day; it looked like grammar that had given up. I followed with the coat and a rope because you cannot stop a woman who has braided with a part of herself that knows ice better than it knows meetings. Pastor came with his hands ready to be useful and his shoulders ready to be scolded by anyone with a badge. Etta did not come because she knows that kitchens need guarding just as much as banks.

The bank behind the old factory has been trying to become a person for years. It was raw and mean and honest. Gideon had gone ahead to the point where he had thrown ropes a hundred times; he threw again and they skated in the wind like insults that refuse to land. The hole in the ice was not large. It was the size of a yes when the wrong person asks. A hat floated near the edge and that was everything. Rook, who had followed against orders I had not given and therefore could not be said to have disobeyed, put the fox down on the bank and the fox’s tile glowed obediently. The light was not much. It was enough. The boy on the ice hung to a lip with a determination I recognized in my own hands when they refuse to drop a stitch. He did not call for help. He conserved.

I lay flat and slid. The coat hissed at the cold but did not scold. She and I breathed like we were trying to persuade the air to remember kindness. Behind me the rope paid out with a grunt from Pastor and a curse from Aunt Sable that rolled over the river’s rudeness like a quilt. Gideon worked the far shore near a tree that has opinions about men who lean on it. “Left,” he called, because there are nights when language collapses to degree and distance. I went left. “There,” he said, and there it was, the slick lip where the boy’s hands had decided to be blasphemers and not let go. I reached and the coat did that thing it does when it remembers it was stitched for this and not for photographs. Heat took the immediate frost and sent it away from the place we stood. I took his wrist. I did not say hold on because he already was. I did not say don’t be afraid because fear was the coat he was wearing and it was keeping him alive.

We pulled. Rook braced his feet on a branch and leaned like he had been born with rope in his family. The Pastor did not pray because he had his hands full. Gideon did not swear because he felt the presence of women. The boy’s elbow slipped and then caught and his mouth opened for a scream that did not arrive because his breath belonged to the river for a second and then to me. We got him out, elbows, knees, hips, laughter that sounded like the underside of ice. We slid him onto a tile we had brought without admitting we had brought it, and the hum sent a message to his bones: you are not going to die of this. It was a lie and a promise, which is what all good spells are.

We took him back to the Retort and resented the way the air forgot it had been cruel ten minutes ago. We stripped him without dignity because dignity is a summer sport. We wrapped him in the coat because coats exist for boys more than for witches. We fed him sugar that has never once saved anyone and saves everyone. He cried for his mother and then didn’t because Etta came and scolded him for drips on her floor and then kissed his ear. The Pastor knelt in the corner and did not make it about God. Rook adjusted the fox’s tail and I decided that if anyone tried to make him take it offstage I would place the tile in their lap and see if their legs learned respect.

The storm blew out and left behind that silvery light that makes the town look like a photograph of itself. People went home boastful and shook and I put the coat back on its hook and told it to stop preening. We slept without dreams because the body has a sense of humor and chooses rest at the absurd times and panic at parties. When I woke, the Retort had cooled enough to tick like a grandfather clock and the tiles looked like squares where an entire town had stood patiently and listened to their own versions of themselves.

The key from my mother’s tin itched in my pocket like an idea that doesn’t want to be caught. It had not been the lock at the Nestlé wall. It did not belong to any door in my shop or to storage under the stairs or to the bookcase with the secret we will all pretend not to know for decades. It wanted a throat. It wanted a particular metal sound. I went to the mill’s underbelly, where the old vents still pretend they are essential. The tunnels smell like iron and adolescent kisses. I put the key to a grate and it shrugged. I put it to a panel that once had a safety sermon on it and it sighed as if remembering. The fourth try was a small innocuous box over a corridor so cold my nostrils threatened to become architecture. The key fit like a pronoun that finally makes sense. Inside was not treasure because treasure would be vulgar. It was paper. It was a rolled plan with clean lines and a date from before my mother decided to have the version of me who likes to embroider feelings onto objects. It was a drawing of a flue and a retort older than any living man in this town by twenty years. It was a way to climb into the old chimney and make it eat correctly.

Nate took one look and said this is stupid and then another look and said let us. He has a love for old systems the way some men love horses or their first wives. He and a girl from the college who wears boots like she owns terrain and uses words like laminar with affection ran their fingers along the map like loved ones at a grave. Gideon fetched a chain that has pulled up four cars and three lies. Delia stood with her device and her pencil and told us where the air would try to cheat. We fitted the old brick to our mouth the way I fit old hems to new fabric. I kissed my mother’s initials scratched in the tin on the corner of my counter because I have given up on pretending there isn’t a river between me and any good decision I make.

When we lit the old stack it coughed like a baritone woken at noon and then cleared its throat and took the breath the way you want a body to take a breath when it has been told it can relax. The draw was easy. The jars showed their data without blushing. The heat held where it should and the coat did not have to be a hero. The town came and stood and did not applaud because this was not a show; it was a day at work. Rook put his ear to the brick and declared the chimney was telling jokes about how it had not expected to be useful again and that it would not be satisfied until someone worked a dance into its shadow. The Pastor took off his hat in the wind and did not chase it and the hat hit the brick and stopped and he looked at me as if the wall had done him a favor.

Morrison came because he has good instincts for victory he can photograph himself near. He put a hand on the old brick and the brick did not warm for him because it is old enough to know the difference between affection and a résumé. He asked about scale, which is always their question, and I told him to ask me about pace instead. He offered money again and Eloise took his card again and then brought it to my shop and stuck it under a wobbly leg without smiling. Delia wrote an email with numbers as polite as she gets. The firefighters came to see if they could be spared eyebrow trauma, and I gave them cuffs and Rook told them the fox is not designed to ride in a truck and they pretended to be offended.

We laid the first run of tile along the river on a day the wind couldn’t make up its mind. It was a patch, not a road, the opposite of a ribbon cutting because only babies and fools cut ribbons that are doing their best to hold something together. Children stepped and shouted and did the thing where they take four hops and then need to tell a story about a bird. Women carrying groceries stood for one extra minute and then another and the bags left their red-purple bites in their fingers and they did not mind. Gideon put a square in his boat with the seriousness he usually reserves for his hat. Etta brought bread and put it straight on the tile for warmth and committed five sins I will never scold her for. Aunt Sable chalked a word on the edge where the next square will go and she did not let me see it until the chalk had failed to brush off with a sleeve.

That night the mirror did not wait for me to stand in front of it. It brightened the way mirrors do when a woman finally lights a candle instead of pretending the dark is not dark. She stood with me and we did not say our names because we both know them and that is not what naming is for. “You stitched the river to the floor,” she observed, generous in the way that makes me wonder what we will do next that will require forgiveness. “You made a chimney behave without shame. You kept a boy from dying and you forced a plant to admit it does not need a fence to be safe.”

“I had help,” I said, and it was not false modesty. I have never in my life done anything of value that didn’t run through other hands like light through a window.

“Keep liking that part,” she said. “Keep asking for rope. Keep making little mouths that don’t scare the city. Do not get good at spectacle. It eats you.”

I wrote a word on the mirror with the fat of my thumb. Keep, I wrote, and the glass fogged and cleared and kept it. I wrote a second word under it because I am greedy and because there is no other point to being a woman who can convince heat to behave. Breathe, I wrote, and the mirror did. We went to bed not early and not late and the coat hung and did not whisper. The Retort cooled with the smug contentment of a thing that has been asked to do a job it was built for. The river moved like a thought I would remember in the morning. The wind bit my eaves and was forgiven.

In the middle of the night my phone hummed with the politeness of a man who has learned how to wake you without making you hate him. It was Gideon, and he was not at the river and he was not apologizing. “The car,” he said in a voice that had placed itself on the map and chosen not to move. “Another. Not old. Not ours. Out by the bend near the flats. I can get it if you want to know who decided to let go. I can leave it if you want to sleep.”

I pulled the quilt up to my chin and let myself lie, because I am learning to leave some things to other people who are good at grief. “Get it,” I said. “Tell me in the morning whether the river wants to punish or forgive. Tell me if the key fits another box. Tell me if I need to get out of bed.”

He made a sound that men make when they are grateful women did not ask their night to be bent. “Sleep,” he said. “Dream of floors.”

I did not dream of floors. I dreamed of hats, ridiculous hats, the kind made out of plastic snow that men wear to stay human in a storm. I dreamed of making them into tiles and then into a roof and then into a deck and then throwing the deck a party and not inviting the men. I dreamed of Morrison learning to hold a wrench and of Delia teaching a class called The Physics of Being Reasonable. I dreamed of Aunt Sable in a dress of anchors and nails. I dreamed of Rook building a creature with no tail at all that ran on insults turned into power. I dreamed of Pastor Lennox standing on a tile and saying the word floor without anyone in his congregation thinking it was a code for witch. I dreamed of my mother writing another note and tucking it under a tile at the river, and I dreamed of letting it stay.

In the morning, the air had that feel of a town that has been behaving itself and would like a treat. I made toast and didn’t judge it for not being better. The tile at my feet hummed with the satisfaction of a tool that had gotten the joke. The coat watched me butter my bread with the suspicion of a garment that fears butter and the long slow creep of everyday. We would get the day anyway. We would get Morrison and the men with triangles turned into squares and the paperwork and the part where people ask if the Jar Lava is safe in a voice that cones the word witch into a new field. We would get a boy coming in with a bag full of bottle caps he had washed with care because he had learned care remains even when you have a mouth for heat. We would get a woman asking if a tile could sit on the sill of her father’s room where he coughs and we would say yes and mean it. We would get Gideon’s call and it would be bad and not unusual. We would get all of it. And the river, rude and spare and patient, would go on making its case for not being anyone’s metaphor. It would let us stand on its breath. It would keep our breath trapped in squares on floors we had the nerve to call beautiful. It would be winter for a while yet, and then it would not be, and we would keep, and we would breathe.
